title: Research on the Operation Optimization of Ground Source Heat Pump Heating System Based on Load Forecasting and Peak-Valley Electricity Prices
affiliations: Southwest Petroleum University - School of Mechatronic Engineering, Southwest Petroleum University and Southwest Petroleum University

detail.title: Research on the Operation Optimization of Ground Source Heat Pump Heating System Based on Load Forecasting and Peak-Valley Electricity Prices

keywords.keywords: ground source heat pump；building energy efficiency；heat load；energy consumption；LSTM-Adaboost

detail.abstract: In order to solve the problem of energy waste caused by the heat pump being turned on for a long time during the heating period of the ground source heat pump system, reduce energy consumption and improve energy efficiency. Based on the ground source heat pump system of a public building in Chengdu, the building load is calculated on the basis of temperature prediction neural networks and combined with the peak and valley electricity price control strategy, the heat pump start-stop time of the ground source heat pump system and the system energy consumption, COP, soil temperature and operating cost within 10 days of operation were compared before and after the optimization of various neural networks prediction models. The results show that the predicted temperature accuracy is increased after the optimization of the long short-term memory network by the integrated algorithm, and the average relative error and average absolute error of the predicted load are reduced by 20.8% and 26.34kW respectively compared with the simulated load. After optimization, the ground source heat pump system can realize the staggered operation of the system through the joint prediction of the load of the hot water storage tank, and the intermittent start of the heat pump unit. The overall performance of the system is significantly improved. The energy consumption of the heat pump and the system is reduced to 181.97kWh and 446.61kWh respectively, and the COP is increased to 4.89 and 3.88 respectively. The decline trend of soil temperature is alleviated, the running time of peak and flat electricity price stages is reduced, the total power consumption is reduced by 1181.54kWh, and the operating cost is reduced by 1155.93CNY. The research results can provide theoretical basis and reference for the optimal design, intelligent operation control and building energy.

title: And Yet it Moves: A Study of Natural Gas Consumption in Italy During the 2022 Energy Crisis
affiliations: Bocconi University - Department of Economics and Bocconi University

detail.title: And Yet it Moves: A Study of Natural Gas Consumption in Italy During the 2022 Energy Crisis
detail.abstract: This paper presents the first econometric analysis of Italian residential natural gas consumption during the 2022 energy crisis. Using daily data from 2012 to 2025 and applying the Autoregressive Distributed Lag (ARDL) and Error Correction Model (ECM) methodologies, we investigate how the unprecedented price shocks following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine affected Italian households’ consumption patterns. Our analysis demonstrates that the crisis triggered a persistent transformation in consumers’ behavior that extends beyond the immediate crisis period. Before December 2021, natural gas demand was essentially price-inelastic. However, the energy crisis altered this relationship, with price elasticity increasing from virtually zero to 0.24 by 2023 — a transformation that persists even as prices have moderated. The elasticity is even larger (up to 1.69) when we refer to the price-responsive component of demand. Moreover, the decomposition of total demand into heating and baseload components reveals that space heating demand served as the primary adjustment mechanism during the crisis. Finally, we estimate approximately 11 billion cubic meters in savings between 2022 and 2024, translating to 10 billion euros in financial benefits.

title: The Energy Transition Dilemma: A Case Study of Nuclear and Solar Energy Development in Taiwan
affiliations: National Chung Hsing University, National Chung Hsing University, National Chung Hsing University and National Chung Hsing University

detail.title: The Energy Transition Dilemma: A Case Study of Nuclear and Solar Energy Development in Taiwan
detail.abstract: Both nuclear and solar energy offer positive externalities by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, yet they present distinct negative externalities. In light of Taiwan’s net-zero commitments and the growing demand for electricity, energy policy must navigate the tension between maintaining power stability and advancing a low-carbon transition. This study employs the Contingent Valuation Method (CVM) to estimate the public’s willingness to pay (WTP) for the negative externalities associated with nuclear power and solar photovoltaics in Taiwan. A nationwide survey yielded 1,231 valid responses, and WTP was estimated using Probit and Logit models. The results reveal a higher sensitivity and WTP regarding the environmental and agricultural impacts of solar energy. The estimated WTP per kilowatt-hour (kWh) for solar energy ranges from NT$9.177 to NT$10.788, resulting in an annual public cost between NT$437.91 billion and NT$514.78 billion. In comparison, the WTP for nuclear power ranges from NT$3.743 to NT$3.83 per kWh, with a corresponding annual national cost between NT$178.63 billion and NT$182.92 billion. These findings suggest a shift in public concern from nuclear safety toward environmental sustainability with notable differences observed across demographic groups. Policy recommendations include enhancing transparency and improving risk communication to strengthen public understanding of energy-related externalities and support informed energy transition strategies.

title: Optimal Monetary Policy and Exchange Rate Regimes in Commodity-Exposed Economies
affiliations: University of Maryland, Bank of England, London School of Economics and London School of Economics

detail.title: Optimal Monetary Policy and Exchange Rate Regimes in Commodity-Exposed Economies
detail.abstract: Is the inflation targeting framework suitable for an environment with commodity price swings? Are there circumstances in which a fixed exchange rate could be beneficial? We study these perennial questions from the perspective of economies that have different exposures to commodity trade. We develop a flexible but tractable model for an economy that imports and/or exports commodities; moreover, in line with empirical evidence, we allow international borrowing conditions to vary endogenously with the commodity cycle, which gives rise to additional costs and benefits of active exchange rate management. By varying the economy’s commodity exposure along these dimensions, we analyze the implied volatility of inflation and activity under different policy rules, and derive the optimal policy. We find that the desirability of different policy configurations critically depends on the economy’s specific commodity exposure. Nonetheless, some form of inflation targeting tends to perform well in a relatively wide range of macroeconomic environments.

title: Effect of Environmental Corporate Social Responsibility on a Dynamic Polluting Oligopoly
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Effect of Environmental Corporate Social Responsibility on a Dynamic Polluting Oligopoly
detail.abstract: This study examines the impact of oligopolistic firms’ environmental corporate social responsibility (CSR) practices on pollution dynamics. A dynamic game model is developed to analyze the strategic interactions among polluting firms that engage in CSR, and to compare the open-loop Nash equilibrium (commitment case) with the Markov perfect Nash equilibrium (no-commitment case). The analysis shows that as firms become more aware of CSR, their production strategies move closer to the socially optimal level, thereby enhancing social welfare. The study explores two distinct scenarios: excessive pollution and underproduction. Notably, even a modest degree of CSR can effectively mitigate excessive pollution. Moreover, in the no-commitment case, there are situations in which increasing the level of CSR can shift a firm’s behavior from underproduction to overproduction. This finding suggests that the socially optimal outcome in an oligopolistic market can be achieved even when firms are only partially concerned with CSR.

title: Rivalries, War, and Trade
affiliations: University of California, Irvine - Department of Economics, University of Richmond - E. Claiborne Robins School of Business and University of Richmond

detail.title: Rivalries, War, and Trade
detail.abstract: We examine how trade is affected by anticipation of a military conflict, as reflected in a strategic rivalry between countries. By combining a recent database of strategic rivalries with information on defense alliances, military conflicts, and bilateral trade for the years 1950-2019, we show that deteriorating relations impact trade independently of the destructive effects of wars. We find that strategic rivalries, where perceive one another as military threats, can significantly suppress trade, especially when the underlying conflicts involve ideological disputes or stem from multiple distinct sources of tension. The effect of rivalries on trade varies significantly over time, with the largest negative effects realized during the Cold War era. Over the entire sample period, accounting for strategic rivalries reduces the estimated impact of wars on trade by nearly 35 percent, suggesting that a significant portion of the trade disruption attributed to wars may actually result from rivalries.

title: ESG Performance and Oil Prices Risk Exposure
affiliations: Renmin University of China, Renmin University of China, Soka University of America and Renmin University of China

detail.title: ESG Performance and Oil Prices Risk Exposure
detail.abstract: This paper investigates whether corporate ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) performance can serve as a strategic hedge against global crude oil price fluctuations. Using a comprehensive panel of firms listed on China’s A-share market, we measure firm-level oil price risk exposure via an augmented CAPM model and apply mixed-effects regression, difference-in-differences estimation, and instrumental variables to address endogeneity. We find that higher ESG ratings significantly reduce firms’ oil price risk exposure, with stronger effects for non-key polluters and derivative users. Mechanism analysis identifies three channels: outward foreign direct investment, improved energy efficiency, and enhanced transparency. Lower exposure to oil price risk translates into reduced bankruptcy probability, underscoring ESG’s role in corporate financial stability.

title: Subsidizing Inequality? The Links between Fossil Fuel Consumption Subsidies and Female Labor Force Participation
affiliations: National and Kapodistrian University of Athens and University of Ioannina

detail.title: Subsidizing Inequality? The Links between Fossil Fuel Consumption Subsidies and Female Labor Force Participation
detail.abstract: The sustainability transition calls for the removal of harmful subsidies and the promotion of gender equality, among other key objectives. While scientific evidence is substantial on the economic and environmental dimensions of fossil fuel consumption subsidies, little is known about their gendered implications. Motivated by recent developments (COP29 climate finance and subsidies’ phasing out, Glasgow Climate Pact) and the knowledge gap on the gender extensions of energy policy, this paper investigates the links between fossil fuel consumption subsidies and female labor force participation. Static and dynamic econometric modelling (Driscoll-Kraay standard errors, method of moments quantile regression, two-step system GMM estimator) are employed on a global sample of 39 countries for the period 2010-2022. Findings confirm the negative relationship between fossil fuel consumption subsidies and female labor force participation rates. The investigation contributes to informed energy economics and policy with a focus on gender trajectories. It sheds light on the social implications of fossil fuel consumption subsidies, suggesting reforms that promote gender inclusion along with environmental and economic goals.

title: Aligning the Fueleu Maritime Regulation with Marginal Cost Principles: A Suggested Correction for the Penalty Structure
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Hasselt University

detail.title: Aligning the Fueleu Maritime Regulation with Marginal Cost Principles: A Suggested Correction for the Penalty Structure
detail.abstract: This article investigates the economic impact and behavioral implications of the FuelEU Maritime (FEUM) regulation, with particular focus on its penalty mechanism designed to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the maritime sector. By modeling the cost-minimizing behavior of a hypothetical ship operator faced with compliance obligations, we derive the marginal abatement cost (MAC) curve implied by the current regulatory framework. Our analysis reveals that the FEUM's multi-tiered penalty structure, comprising the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS), a GHG intensity penalty, and a Renewable Fuel of Non-Biological Origin (RFNBO) blending sub-target, introduces discontinuities and non-monotonicity in the MAC curve. These distortions undermine economic efficiency by generating inconsistent incentives for emissions abatement. We propose a revised penalty function that replaces the original formulation with a linear structure, thereby restoring monotonicity in the MAC without altering overall compliance stringency. Simulations demonstrate that the proposed revision significantly reduces cost irregularities, particularly from 2035 onward when regulatory stringency increases. This paper contributes to the design of more effective environmental regulation by aligning incentive structures with economic theory, ultimately supporting the EU’s maritime decarbonization goals.

title: Time-Varying Higher-Order Moments of Crude Oil Futures: The Role of Climate Risks
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Hull

detail.title: Time-Varying Higher-Order Moments of Crude Oil Futures: The Role of Climate Risks
detail.abstract: Highlights• We estimate time-varying higher-order moments (TV-HoMs) of crude oil futures.• We link these TV-HoMs to climate risks at the regional and global levels.• Climate risks raise asymmetries in crude oil futures while reducing heavy-tailedness.• They also improve out-of-sample forecasts of crude oil TV-HoMs.• Improvements are greater for time-varying skewness than for kurtosis.

title: Equity Financing and Exports: Evidence from IPO Approvals in China
affiliations: HKUST Business School, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology - School of Business and Management, Department of Economics; HKUST IEMS (Institute for Emerging Market Studies), City University of Hong Kong (CityU) and Columbia University - Columbia Business School, Finance

detail.title: Equity Financing and Exports: Evidence from IPO Approvals in China
detail.abstract: This study provides the first empirical analysis of how access to equity financing affects firm exports. We leverage the unique institutional setting of China, where IPOs required a stringent approval process, ensuring that only sufficiently qualified firms advance to the final IPO review meetings. Our empirical strategy compares the export performance of successful IPO applicants with that of "near misses"-applicants rejected at the final IPO review meetings. To sharpen identification, we utilize review meeting records to exclude rejections citing concerns about revenue growth or profitability risks, as these may entail unobserved factors that also influence a firm's future export performance. Our difference-in-differences analysis reveals that IPO approval leads to a significant annualized increase of more than 6% in firm exports. IPO approval primarily affects the extensive margin, enabling firms to expand into more destination-product markets. Further evidence suggests that IPOs enhance exports by financing export-related intangible investments and risk-taking activities.

title: Financial Globalization: Risk Sharing or Risk Exposure?
affiliations: National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) and University of Southern California - Marshall School of Business - Finance and Business Economics Department

detail.title: Financial Globalization: Risk Sharing or Risk Exposure?
detail.abstract: We study how the increased cross-country ownership of financial assets between advanced and emerging economies impacted their financial and macroeconomic volatility. While cross-country ownership improved risk-sharing and reduced volatility associated with financial crises, it also increased the exposure of countries to foreign crises, leading to higher international co-movement. Through quantitative applications of a two-region model representative of advanced and emerging economies, we find that financial globalization reduced volatility worldwide, but significantly more in emerging economies.

title: Labor Mobility and the Level of Unemployment in a Currency Union
affiliations: University of Michigan at Ann Arbor - Department of Economics, University of Michigan at Ann Arbor - Department of Economics, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL) and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Labor Mobility and the Level of Unemployment in a Currency Union
detail.abstract: Unemployment rates are higher and more volatile in the euro area relative to the United States. We ask to what extent the lack of cross-country labor mobility can account for unemployment dynamics in Europe. Our analytical model incorporates downward nominal wage rigidity and an endogenous migration decision. Firms are unable to freely adjust wages during economic contractions, generating an asymmetric distribution of unemployment over the business cycle. The model is calibrated to the dynamics of unemployment and net migration in a typical euro area country. An increase in labor mobility to that observed in the United States and holding all other parameters fixed would reduce the volatility of euro area unemployment by 40% and return 1 million unemployed to the workforce. The welfare cost to a typical euro area country of the currency union is 4.7 percent of permanent consumption; increasing labor mobility reduces this cost to about 4.1 percent.

title: The Sentiment Exchange Marketplace: A New Emotional Economy for Ethical Transactions
affiliations: University of the People

detail.title: The Sentiment Exchange Marketplace: A New Emotional Economy for Ethical Transactions
detail.abstract:
This article extends the Sentiment Exchange framework (Campagnolo, 2025), introducing a blockchain-based marketplace that tokenizes the emotional impact of companies, celebrities, influencers, politicians, political parties, organizations in general (e.g., NGOs, cultural associations), public figures (e.g., activists, thought leaders), and humanitarian organizations, such as the World Food Programme (WFP), to create a transformative emotional economy. Emotional indices—Brand Sentiment Index for companies, Influence Index for influencers, Sentiment Index for politicians and public figures, Social Impact Index for organizations, Resilience Index for the WFP—are calculated using E$ = Σ (S × W), where S aggregates emotional scores from biometric, social, or programmatic data, and W incorporates ethical and cultural weights via AI-driven algorithms. Entities are quoted based on these indices, and E$ tokens enable transactions for personalized experiences, marketing campaigns, political funding, social initiatives, advocacy programs, and humanitarian efforts. Addressing the genericity, repetition, and theoretical limitations of Author (2025), this study provides detailed technical specifications (Polygon 2.0 blockchain, federated learning, zero-knowledge proofs) and robust ethical safeguards, including an enhanced Emotional Equity Index (EEI), smart contract governance, and GDPR-inspired regulations to mitigate commodification (Sandel, 2012), surveillance (Zuboff, 2019), cultural bias, and digital inequities. Illustrative scenarios demonstrate impact: a retailer generates €6 million in sales, an influencer monetizes exclusive content, a public figure funds advocacy campaigns, an NGO supports community projects, and the WFP funds 1.5 million school meals in South Sudan. Aligned with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG 2 (Zero Hunger), the marketplace fosters ethical business innovation. Pilot studies, including a WFP collaboration, are proposed to validate the framework. This study contributes to business ethics by offering a scalable, equitable model for an emotional economy, urging global policymakers to regulate emotional data.


Note: The reference to the Journal of Business Ethics concerns a manuscript that was submitted to the journal but was not accepted for publication.

title: City Profile: Contested Terrains, Land, Informality, and Dispossession in the Making of Urban Siliguri
affiliations: University of Gour Banga and CEntre for the study of Regional Development

detail.title: City Profile: Contested Terrains, Land, Informality, and Dispossession in the Making of Urban Siliguri
detail.abstract: This urban profile of Siliguri presents a grounded, interdisciplinary analysis of urban change in the foothills of the Himalayas, where rapid expansion collides with ecological fragility and institutional fragmentation. Approaching the city through a political-economic lens, the study views land not merely as a commodity but as a deeply contested socio-political terrain shaped by informality, speculative interests, and hybrid forms of governance. What distinguishes this study is its integrated perspective on land management, peri-urban transformation, and environmental risk, treating them as interwoven dynamics rather than isolated challenges. Siliguri’s strategic role as a corridor city linking the Indian plains with the eastern Himalayas renders it an important site for examining complex patterns of spatial accumulation and uneven development. Informal urban expansion, particularly on former tea estates, coupled with land brokerage networks and the complicity of state actors, has transformed the urban periphery into a fragmented and loosely regulated frontier. The work also highlights how informality operates not just as a survival mechanism but as a deliberate governance strategy that shapes access to infrastructure and perpetuates spatial inequalities across the city. The profile calls for a more inclusive, environmentally conscious, and regionally coordinated governance model to ensure a sustainable urban future.

title: Brief of Law Professors Sharon K. Sandeen and David S. Levine, as Amici Curiae in Support of Pegasystems, Inc.
affiliations: Mitchell Hamline School of Law and Elon University School of Law

detail.title: Brief of Law Professors Sharon K. Sandeen and David S. Levine, as Amici Curiae in Support of Pegasystems, Inc.

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Amici are law professors who collectively have more than 50 years of experience teaching, researching, and writing about trade secret law. In addition to the numerous law review articles they have written on the topic, Amici are co-authors of a casebook titled “Information Law, Governance, and Cybersecurity” (West Academic Publishing 2019). Amici have no personal interest in the outcome of this case and are solely interested in the proper application of trade secret law because its limits reflect important concerns related to information diffusion, competition, and due process.

detail.abstract:
The scope of trade secret protection, as reflected in the text of Virginia’s trade secret law, is limited for important reasons. Under the statutory structure, there are two essential issues: (1) the existence of a trade secret; and (2) acts of misappropriation. Microstrategy, Inc. v. Li, 268 Va. 249, 263 (2004). The issue of wrongdoing is not intended to affect the trade secrecy analysis—the trial court is required to properly manage the case to ensure that the trade secrecy and misappropriation analyses are separate inquiries.

To properly frame this analysis, Amici begin with a brief background on how trade secret law fits within the broader context of U.S. intellectual property law and information policy and then explain the proper legal framework for addressing a trade secret misappropriation claim.

title: Value of Temporary Use in Real Estate: A Systematic Literature Review
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and TU Delft

detail.title: Value of Temporary Use in Real Estate: A Systematic Literature Review
detail.abstract: Temporary Use (TU) of vacant real estate have become increasingly recognized as a tool for urban regeneration, yet the understanding of the value(s) they generate remains fragmented and unclear. This systematic literature review examines 25 years of academic publications -from 2000 to 2025- to clarify meanings, dimensions, and assessment methods of the value of TU in vacant real estate. Drawing on value theory, the study identifies three core dimensions: intrinsic value (worth and meaning), extrinsic value (measurable benefits and impacts), and systemic value (cultural and ethical perspectives). The analysis reveals that while TUs generate multi-dimensional values, as economic, social, cultural, and environmental, most scholarly attention has focused on economic and social value, with environmental value still underrepresented. Use value emerges as a central concept especially in grassroots and community-led initiatives, discussed in contrast with market-driven exchange value. Most of assessment methods range from qualitative case study analysis to comparative qualitative analysis, but Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) offer frameworks to evaluate multiple dimensions of both tangible and intangible benefits and impacts. The review evidences the difficulties of capturing values through singular metrics and demonstrate that systemic cultural value in stakeholder dynamics significantly influence how extrinsic added value is created and sustained. These findings advocates for a value-focused approach in real estate reuse and planning to guide equitable and sustainable value distribution for stakeholders, real estate and urban contexts.

title: Origins of Locality: How Local Search Emerges Through Generalization
affiliations: Aarhus University and National University of Singapore (NUS) - NUS Business School

detail.title: Origins of Locality: How Local Search Emerges Through Generalization
detail.abstract: In searching for solutions, organizational decision-makers often exhibit local search, limiting their long-term adaptability in complex environments. Existing explanations attribute local search to either cognitive (e.g., absorptive capacity) or social constraints (e.g., conflicts) that prevent agents from pursuing distant alternatives. However, recent experimental studies find that individuals may still engage in local search even without such constraints. Here, we introduce "learning through generalization" as a mechanism that can produce local search behaviors independently. Using computational modeling, we demonstrate that locality in search behaviors can endogenously emerge through generalization, especially when generalization breadth-i.e., the extent to which agents generalize experience from one alternative to others-is neither too narrow nor too broad. Ironically, our result shows that the intermediate generalization breadth, while producing local search, can actually help agents reach the global peak. Our model contributes to a nuanced view of local search and highlights the intertwined relationship between learning and search in adaptation.

title: Global Data Privacy 2025: International Agreements Stall
affiliations: Macquarie University - Macquarie Law School (Sydney, Australia)

detail.title: Global Data Privacy 2025: International Agreements Stall
detail.abstract:
What progress has been made on global and regional data privacy agreements in the last two years (2023-24)? The previous biennial review (2021-22) concluded that development of international standards had largely stalled, subject to some post-Brexit disruption by the UK.

The last two years - the subject of this current review - see only halting progress resuming. But a lack of major progress does not mean a lack of activity.

Findings of EU ‘adequacy’ under the GDPR for the 11 countries and territories found adequate under the DPD remain in place. No other new adequacy decisions have been made since January 2023, except in relation to the US and the EU-US Data Privacy Framework, and to the European Patent Organisation (EPO). Adequacy remains stalled.

The US Department of Justice the issued a Rule restricting transactions involving certain types of data with six countries of concern, possibly signalling a broader US effort to tighten control over cross-border data flows.

Ratifications of Convention 108+ did not increase in 2024, but have increased by two to 33 during 2025, still leaving a short-fall of five more ratifications for it to come into force.

Sixteen countries have ratified Africa’s Malabo Convention, so it is now in force between them, having reached the requirement of 15 ratifications.

The ‘ECOWAS laws’ (those made to conform with the Supplementary Act under the ECOWAS Treaty) are among the strongest data privacy laws in Africa. Eleven of the fifteen ECOWAS states had enacted data privacy laws by 2023, with none of the remaining four doing so in 2023-24. However, in 2024, the military governments of three countries announced their withdrawal from the bloc.

Despite much ruffling of feathers, the Cross-Border Privacy Rules System (CBPRs), both APEC and ‘Global’ versions, is still a dead parrot. Read about it if you care.

Free trade agreements (FTAs) are not dead, provided the US is not a party. The Comprehensive and Progressive Trans Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) is in force  with 12 parties.  The UK made a formal accession request to the CPTPP as part of its post-Brexit trade arrangements. Accession occurred on 15 July 2023, and has been ratified by both the UK Parliament and by eight of the other 11 initial parties.

Asia-Pacific FTAs now provide three different models for the permissible breadth of data export restrictions, and data localisation: USMCA (most strict); CPTPP (possibly intermediate); and RCEP (most permissive). One or other of these models is being followed in many bilateral FTAs in the Asia-Pacific and elsewhere (e.g. UK-Japan FTA).

The goal of finding the right balance that provides both a high standard of personal data protection and minimal restrictions on overseas transfers remains elusive.

title: Predictive Workforce Planning: Leveraging AI & ML for Optimized HR Strategies and Employee Performance
affiliations: CMR University, Independent, CMR University and CMR University

detail.title: Predictive Workforce Planning: Leveraging AI & ML for Optimized HR Strategies and Employee Performance
detail.abstract: The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) is transforming workforce planning and employee relations. This article explores how AI and ML can simulate human resources (HR) decision-making processes, providing a data-driven approach to workforce management. These technologies analyse large datasets to enhance talent forecasting, skill gap assessments, and employee engagement strategies. The study focuses on improving decision-making in recruitment, retention, performance evaluation, and workforce diversity, resulting in more agile HR operations. Additionally, it addresses ethical implications and challenges related to AI and ML integration in HR, such as transparency, bias mitigation, and privacy concerns. The research aims to identify key employee performance metrics that can be predicted using AI and ML, assess the impact of AI-driven workforce planning on HR strategy optimization, and evaluate the accuracy of various machine learning algorithms in simulating workforce dynamics. Using a mixed-methods approach, including quantitative analysis of HR data and evaluations of algorithms like decision trees and neural networks, the study finds that AI and ML significantly enhance employee performance forecasting, leading to improved HR decision-making and optimized recruitment and training processes. Overall, the research highlights the critical role of AI and ML in modern HR practices, offering practical insights for professionals seeking to leverage technology for effective workforce management in the tech industry.

title: Reaco-Kgc: A Reasoning-Enhanced and Interaction-Corrective Framework Based on Large Language Models for Knowledge Graph Completion
affiliations: Anhui Agricultural University, Anhui Agricultural University, Anhui Agricultural University, University of North Texas, Anhui Agricultural University and Hefei University of Technology

detail.title: Reaco-Kgc: A Reasoning-Enhanced and Interaction-Corrective Framework Based on Large Language Models for Knowledge Graph Completion
detail.abstract: Knowledge Graph Completion (KGC) aims to infer missing entities for in complete triples. Traditional embedding-based methods rely solely on the graph structural information, making limited use of textual semantics. Although emerging text-based methods, i.e., utilizing large language models (LLMs) to learn semantic information, can solve the aforementioned problems to some extent. They still face limitations: 1) Due to the extensive scale of knowledge graphs, prompt information is often lengthy, making it difficult for LLMs to focus on key information when processing long texts; 2) When dealing with semantically similar entities, LLMs often struggle to capture subtle differences between them, leading to insufficient discriminative capability and resulting in confusion. To address these challenges, we propose a reasoning-enhanced and interaction-corrective framework based on large language models for knowledge graph completion (ReaCo-KGC). First, a two-stage prompting mechanism is designed to enable LLMs to extract key information and reasoning processes from in-context information, i.e., adjacent triples, helping LLMs focus on the core content. In addition, a multi-agent re-ranking component that applies a turn-taking summarization strategy is proposed to refine the results and resolve confusion caused by semantic similarity. Moreover, we reduce the candidate set size effectively by using a lightweight model to eliminate irrelevant entities. Experiments on benchmark datasets FB15k-237 and WN18RR demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed framework, validating its effectiveness.

title: Managing Multi-Generational Workforces: Challenges for HR
affiliations: Rashtrasant Tukdoji Maharaj Nagpur University

detail.title: Managing Multi-Generational Workforces: Challenges for HR
detail.abstract: The contemporary workplace presents unprecedented complexity with up to five distinct generations working simultaneously, each bringing unique values, communication styles, and workplace expectations. This research paper examines the critical challenges facing Human Resources professionals in managing multi-generational workforces, with particular focus on the emerging dynamics as Generation Z enters the workforce in greater numbers while Baby Boomers extend their careers. Through analysis of current research and industry trends through 2025, this paper identifies key management strategies, communication frameworks, and policy adaptations necessary for successful multi-generational workforce integration. The findings reveal that while generational differences create significant challenges in areas such as communication preferences, work-life balance expectations, and technology adoption, organizations that successfully leverage generational diversity through targeted HR strategies achieve higher employee satisfaction, reduced turnover, and improved innovation outcomes.

title: CitizenssApp: Digital Empowerment Is a Right, Not a Privilege

detail.title: CitizenssApp: Digital Empowerment Is a Right, Not a Privilege

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no personal or financial interests related to this work. This research was conducted with the intention of advancing digital empowerment and ensuring that everyone has the right to access basic software functionality, such as Create, Read, Update, and Delete (CRUD) operations, without restriction. No funding, sponsorship, or commercial interests have influenced the content of this whitepaper. The author declares no personal or financial conflicts of interest. The aim of this work is to promote universal access to essential software capabilities.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This work does not involve human participants, patients, or case studies; therefore, ethics approval was not required.
declarations.funderStatement: This research and software development were conducted independently by the author, without any external funding or sponsorship. CitizenssApp is provided as free software, with the intention of ensuring that every citizen has access to essential digital tools. The only potential cost for users would relate to data usage, not for the software itself. No external funding was received for this work. The software is provided free of charge as a basic right, with only data usage fees applicable.

detail.abstract: CitizenssApp: Digital Empowerment Is a Right, Not a Privilege Vision "Digital empowerment is no longer a privilege-it is a fundamental need for every citizen. CRUD is the new pen and paper." In today's world, just as reading and writing are essential skills, so too is the ability to engage with digital tools. Every citizen should have the power to create, manage, and use digital applications without technical barriers or dependency on costly developers. CitizenssApp is built on the belief that enabling basic software functionality-like CRUD operations-is no longer optional; it is an essential right. Most citizens already own smartphones or computing devices. They should be able to use them like pen and paperindependently and securely. The lack of access to simple application functionality becomes a form of digital exclusion. This is a digital necessity for every citizen. CRUD is the new literacy. CitizenssApp exists to democratize software creation by removing cost, complexity, and dependency. Philosophical Foundation In the analog world, every citizen could record business, personal, or transactional information using pen and paper. In the digital world, that same simplicity should exist. Once a citizen knows the structure of an entity-like a Customer, Invoice, or Attendancethey should be able to create and manage that data without needing a developer.

title: Multi-Image Compressive Encryption Via a Dynamic Delayed Feedback Chaotic System and Synchronized Fractal Diffusion
affiliations: Northeastern University, Northeastern University, Northeastern University, Northeastern University and Northeastern University

detail.title: Multi-Image Compressive Encryption Via a Dynamic Delayed Feedback Chaotic System and Synchronized Fractal Diffusion
detail.abstract: To ensure the security and transmission efficiency of multiple images, this paper proposes a compressive encryption algorithm based on synchronized fractal diffusion. Firstly, a novel one-dimensional Sinusoidal Dynamic Delayed Feedback Logistic chaotic system (1D-SDFL) is introduced, which provides a secure key stream for the images. Experimental results demonstrate that the system possesses a wider chaotic parameter range and superior chaotic properties. During encryption, a self-similar Fractal Stair Scrambling Matrix (FSSM) is constructed to enhance spatial scrambling. Specifically, multiple images are sparsely represented using the 2D Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) and scrambled through index sorting. Then, different measurement matrices generated via dynamic sampling of the 1D-SDFL system are used to compress the scrambled matrices. Subsequently, the compressed images undergo synchronized scrambling and diffusion using the FSSM. Finally, a Global Multi-image Equal-value Insertion (GMEI) disruption is performed to produce the final encrypted image. The experimental results show that the proposed algorithm performs well in terms of NPCR (99.6096%), UACI (33.4585%), and PSNR (31.9636 dB, CR = 0.25), and demonstrates high security and excellent reconstruction quality.

title: Dual Contrastive Learning with Behavior Pattern Modeling for Session-Based Recommendation

detail.title: Dual Contrastive Learning with Behavior Pattern Modeling for Session-Based Recommendation
detail.abstract: Session-based recommendation (SBR) that provides personalized predictions based on anonymous users’ short-term clicks has recently gained widespread attention. Nowadays, numerous SBR models overlook the joint extraction of explicit and implicit feedback, leading to biases in user behavior modeling. Meanwhile, most methods fail to fully leverage the latent information in repeated items and click orders within sessions, exacerbating the negative effects of data sparsity in SBR. To address the above issues, we propose the Dual Contrastive Learning with Behavior Pattern Modeling (DCL-BPM) method, which maximizes the use of short-term session information while extracting long-range user dependencies for recommendation. Specifically, we first employ GGNN and E-GNN to extract implicit and explicit feedback separately, effectively combining them to construct an accurate dynamic user profile. We then add the filtered session embeddings to prevent data loss caused by gradient mismatch. To better capture user preferences, we design a Dual Contrastive Loss (DCL) framework that constructs negative samples through deduplication and random reshuffling, highlighting the critical role of item frequency and click orders in positive samples during training. DCL is not limited by the network architecture, making it easily adaptable to diverse scenarios in SBR. Extensive experiments on three representative datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our model and its practical value in realworld applications.

title: Integration as the Path to Peace: A Strategic Framework to End the War in Ukraine

detail.title: Integration as the Path to Peace: A Strategic Framework to End the War in Ukraine
detail.abstract: This article proposes a paradigm shift in peacebuilding strategy for the Russia-Ukraine war and broader Eastern European stability. It argues that the prevailing Western approach-centered on sanctions, military deterrence, and diplomatic isolation-has failed to produce a durable resolution. Instead, it has entrenched authoritarian resilience and reinforced adversarial narratives. Drawing on behavioral political theory, the article introduces the concept of Authoritarian Loss Aversion, which posits that autocratic regimes resist compromise due to existential fears of regime collapse and loss of legitimacy. This psychological and institutional dynamic renders traditional coercive strategies counterproductive. In response, the article presents the Integration Paradigm: a strategic framework that replaces confrontation with structured inclusion. It rests on three interdependent pillars-Ukraine's permanent neutrality, phased territorial restoration, and conditional integration of Ukraine, Russia, and Belarus into the European Economic Area (EEA). This model reframes compromise as transformation, offering authoritarian regimes a face-saving exit from conflict while embedding them in legal and economic systems that incentivize reform. The article outlines policy recommendations for EU and international actors, including multilateral treaty design, transitional governance mechanisms, and generational engagement strategies. It also engages with ethical foundations rooted in Kantian cosmopolitanism and Just Peace Theory, emphasizing reconciliation, dignity, and shared prosperity. Ultimately, the Integration Paradigm offers a blueprint for durable peace-one that transforms adversaries into partners through strategic inclusion rather than punitive isolation.

detail.abstract: The increasing reliance on Artificial Intelligence (AI) for decision-making in complex systems, such as financial risk management, healthcare diagnosis, smart transportation, and cybersecurity, necessitates the development of transparent and interpretable solutions. This paper proposes a novel approach, Neuro-Symbolic Optimization, which combines the strengths of neural networks (for complex pattern recognition) and symbolic reasoning (for explainability and logical deduction). This work lays a foundation for future systems that are both intelligent and accountable.

detail.title: Maze-Guard: Anonymous Attribute Certification for Blockchain Access Control Using Zksnarks
detail.abstract: Multi-party business workflows inherently involve semi-trusted actors whose collaboration is essential yet whose divergent interests necessitate controlled and selective data sharing. While public blockchain platforms offer decentralized and immutable ledgers that enhance transparency and auditability, their intrinsic openness often conflicts with enterprise demands for confidentiality and fine-grained access control. To address this tension, we introduce MAZE-Guard, a cryptographic framework that seamlessly integrates Multi-Authority Attribute-Based Encryption (MA-ABE) with Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) to enable scalable, privacy-preserving data sharing in decentralized environments. Distinct from prior work that primarily leverages ZKPs for access verification, MAZE-Guard emphasizes the anonymization of user authority interactions during the attribute key issuance phase—effectively mitigating metadata leakage and preventing attribute inference. Sensitive messages are fragmented and encrypted under expressive, multi-authority attribute policies, allowing only qualified participants to access protected content. Crucially, user eligibility is validated using Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Arguments of Knowledge (zkSNARKs), ensuring cryptographic compliance with access policies without disclosing attribute values or user identities. A proof-of-concept implementation on Ethereum compatible platforms demonstrates that MAZE-Guard incurs only 101,000 gas for its sole on-chain verification step, achieves sub-125 ms latency across core cryptographic operations, and scales efficiently with increasing attribute complexity. These results underscore MAZE-Guard’s practicality as a robust and verifiable framework for secure, fine-grained collaboration in decentralized multi-party systems.

detail.title: Sparsity-Resilient Qos Prediction Via Ε-Dp Enhanced Subgraph-Inductive Gnns in Internet of Services
detail.abstract: The rapid evolution of the Internet of Services (IoS) in the Web 3.0 era empowers users with access to an abundance of functionally similar services. This makes reliable Quality of Service (QoS) prediction essential for selecting optimal services. However, real-world QoS data often suffer from high sparsity, and privacy concerns frequently prevent users from sharing their raw QoS records. This creates a dual challenge: achieving high prediction accuracy while preserving data privacy in sparse environments. To address these challenges, we propose DPIS-GNN, a novel framework that integrates ε-Differential Privacy (ε-DP) with subgraph-inductive Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). Our approach first applies ε-DP mechanisms to obfuscate local datasets, protecting sensitive user information. These perturbed datasets are then aggregated into a unified interaction graph, from which relevant patterns are inferred. Next, we introduce a subgraph-based GNN that inductively learns from the noisy and sparse data to produce accurate QoS predictions. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach. DPIS-GNN achieves up to a 17.55% reduction in Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and a 9.77% decrease in Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), outperforming state-of-the-art baselines. Our model exhibits superior robustness in sparse and cold-start scenarios, offering both strong privacy protection and high predictive performance.

detail.title: Losing Political Representation
detail.abstract: What are the consequences of losing political representation in a democracy? A reform of Germany’s mixed electoral system left more than 7 million citizens in 23 constituencies without a directly elected representative after the 2025 national election. Which and how many constituencies were affected was unpredictable and quasi-random. We show that losing political representation reduces citizens’ satisfaction with democracy. Moreover, discontent is independent of party preferences and spreads through social networks, reducing democratic satisfaction even among individuals who were unaware of the reform’s outcome. Political representation is a cornerstone of democracy; its erosion may give rise to democratic backsliding.

detail.title: Fedckd: Trusted Personalized Federated Learning Based on Clustering and Knowledge Distillation
detail.abstract: Currently, many smart IoT services and applications are emerging, and federated learning has emerged to train global models by effectively leveraging the large amount of user-generated data on IoT devices. However, in practical applications, the training data across different user terminals are often non-iid. When the data distribution among user terminals is very different, the performance of the model will be greatly reduced if the knowledge learned from other user terminals is directly obtained. Furthermore, federated learning does not offer robust privacy protection, posing a privacy leakage risk during parameter uploading. To address these issues, we propose FedCKD, a trusted personalized federated learning method based on clustering and knowledge distillation. Considering the negative impact of mitigating the non-iid data, a personalized model is obtained for each client through clustering and knowledge distillation. Firstly, a K-means clustering algorithm based on Canopy is used. Then, it uses cyclic knowledge distillation to extract common knowledge, and performes re-learning to achieve personalization. Our approach also implements privacy protection using a distributed differential privacy mechanism based on a shuffling algorithm. Extensive experiments show that FedCKD performs significantly better than state-of-the-art baselines. Code for the experiments in this work can be found at https://github.com/LIUrxxxx/FedCKD.

detail.title: Quantifying the Impacts of Weather Year Selection on Power Sector Capacity Expansion Models
detail.abstract: Power system capacity expansion models (CEMS)  inform optimal investment in the electricity grid but are dependent on assumptions about the future grid, including hourly electricity demand shapes and renewable availability profiles. Modelers often base these profiles on a single year of data. Because weather impacts generation performance and electricity demand, it is important to ensure CEMs use same-year load and renewable energy production profiles. However, the user is often left to decide which base year to use. Because different years have different load and renewable energy shapes, future projections based on any particular year might yield different optimal futures. The purpose of this study is to test that assumption and assess the impact of the baseline weather year selection on investment decisions made by CEMs for future generation development. We ran twenty CEM simulations of ERCOT from 2022-2050, each with a distinct base weather year from 2002-2021. We find negligible variation with weather year for the bulk grid-wide capacity and energy results, but found that variations in regional capacity, total costs, and emissions were more significant. While these deviations might be tolerable for many projects, we conclude that utilizing multiple weather years will improve model accuracy. Our results indicate that the share of electricity generated by variable sources is consistent across weather years, although the specific mix exhibits noticeable variation. We discover that the precision of simulations with multiple temporal stages can be improved without additional computational cost by utilizing data from a separate weather year during each model period.

Complex parts can be produced using this method at affordable costs, often inferior to other additive manufacturing methods. This article presents a review of previous study on the FDM process to inform research perspectives and investigate the strategies needed to improve dimensional accuracy.

detail.abstract: This study investigates the poverty reduction gains that are associated with access to digital technologies by using panel data based on 113 countries from 2000 to 2022. We address crosssectional and temporal dependency with the Driscoll-Kraay technique, and endogeneity with the Lewbel two-stage least squares technique. The results indicate that the digital technology access index—comprising broadband, telephone, mobile, and internet access—contributes to poverty reduction, with the effect being persistent. Except for mobile phone usage, the rest of the digital technology proxies do not follow the critical mass hypothesis. Mediation analysis indicates that access to digital technologies contributes to poverty reduction by working through increasing gross domestic product per capita; accessing finance, education, and employment; and reducing income inequality. The poverty reduction gains of digital technologies are evident in developing Asia, landlocked/island nations, coastal/non-island countries, and advanced economies, with broadband and internet access contributing to poverty reduction during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. Given the role of digital technologies in strengthening resilience, we call on policymakers to invest in and expand digital connectivity, particularly to vulnerable communities.

detail.title: Top Management Team Diversity and ESG
detail.abstract: This paper investigates why TMT diversity has an inconsistent impact on ESG performance, arguing its effectiveness is contingent on cultural norms of hierarchy. In hierarchical cultures, such as South Korea's, these norms can suppress diverse perspectives and weaken ESG outcomes. We examine this through age-based authority, a prominent cultural feature, using a novel "Age-Rank Hierarchy Alignment Index" to measure when formal rank mirrors seniority based on age. Our analysis reveals that both age diversity and a strong alignment between age and rank independently harm ESG performance. This alignment reduces conflict by silencing dissenting voices, not by fostering the deliberation needed for strong ESG strategy. Ultimately, the study provides a framework for how formalizing cultural hierarchies can neutralize the benefits of TMT diversity.

detail.abstract: The research addresses the critical importance of adopting sustainable practices in the construction industry, particularly in light of environmental degradation caused by rapid urbanisation, globalisation, and climate change. The main argument raised by the chapter is that immersive technology, including Virtual Reality (VR), Augmented Reality (AR), and Building Information Modelling (BIM), can play a transformative role in promoting sustainability and effective environmental management practices within the construction sector. The chapter aims to critically analyse how immersive technology can address global environmental challenges and contribute to sustainable building practices throughout the construction lifecycle. The research employs a quantitative research methodology involving an examination of existing construction practices globally. The research findings suggest that when appropriately integrated, immersive technology can facilitate virtual design and visualisation processes, conduct energy simulations and analyses for optimised energy efficiency, support sustainable material selection and life cycle assessments, and promote efficient construction waste management. Consequently, these applications significantly reduce the environmental impacts of construction projects. The study underscores the critical importance of widespread adoption and utilisation of immersive technology to foster sustainable construction practices globally, highlighting its potential to mitigate environmental degradation and promote environmentally conscious decision-making throughout the construction industry. Future research could focus on developing advanced algorithms and tools within immersive technology platforms to optimise sustainable design parameters. This could involve incorporating machine learning and artificial intelligence techniques to automate the process of energy simulations, material selection, and life cycle assessments, thereby enhancing the efficiency and accuracy of sustainable design optimisation.

detail.title: Real Time Rail Electrification Systems Monitoring: A Review of Technologies
detail.abstract: Most electrified railway networks are powered through a pantograph-Overhead Contact Line (OCL) interface to ensure safe and reliable operation. The OCL is one of the most vulnerable components of the train traction power system as it is subjected to multiple impacts from the pantographs and to unpredictable environmental conditions. Wear, mounting imperfections, contact incidents, weather conditions and inadequate maintenance leads to increased degradation of the pantograph-OCL current collection performance, causing degradation on contacting elements and assets failure. Incidents involving the pantograph-OCL system are significant sources of traffic disruption and train delays. E.g., Network Rail statistics show that, on average, delays due to OCL failures are 2500 hours per year. In recent years, maintenance strategies have evolved significantly with improvements in technology and the increased interest of using real-time and historical data in decision support. This has led to an expansion in sensing systems for structures, vehicles and machinery. The railway industry is currently investing in Condition Monitoring (CM) technologies in order to achieve lower failure rates, and increased availability, reliability and safety of the railway service. This work presents a comprehensive review on the current CM systems for pantograph-OCL, including their advantages and disadvantages, and outlines future trends in this area.

detail.title: Smarten V2.0: A Scalable Framework for Multiscale Energy Forecasting in Interconnected Buildings Toward Smarter Grid Management
detail.abstract: As the global energy sector moves toward decentralized and renewable systems, accurate forecasting tools are crucial for optimizing energy management and grid operations. This study presents enhancements to the SMARTEN v2.0 framework, a cutting edge time series forecasting algorithm designed to predict energy consumption and production with high precision. A key innovation is its scaling technique, which adjusts for seasonal and daily fluctuations, improving reliability in dynamic environments. SMARTEN v2.0 was tested using high-resolution datasets from two distinct locations: the Mafate microgrid in a tropical climate with minimal seasonal variation, and the GreEn-ER building in a semi continental mountainous region. These contrasting sites provided a robust basis for evaluating the model’s adaptability across diverse energy profiles. Performance metrics including RMSE, R², and MAE demonstrate SMARTEN v2.0’s strong ability to replicate energy trends, particularly under stable conditions. In both annual and monthly simulations, the model closely matches measured values, confirming its effectiveness in capturing long-term energy dynamics. Importantly, the normalized RMSE (nRMSE) remains below 20%, aligning with benchmarks found in scientific literature for similar forecasting studies. This supports the model’s credibility and places its predictive accuracy within accepted standards. However, the model faces challenges when forecasting irregular consumption patterns, such as those occurring during weekends and public holidays. These anomalies highlight the need for further refinements to improve accuracy in scenarios with non-standard behavior. Despite these limitations, SMARTEN v2.0 performs reliably in contexts involving photovoltaic production and consistent energy use.

detail.abstract: The Industrial Internet of Things has generated substantial amounts of high-dimensional tensor data, making anomaly detection crucial for manufacturing safety and efficiency.  The one-class support vector machine, intended for vector-based data, frequently struggles to manage the intricacies of large-scale IIoT data.  To address these restrictions, we provide the One-Class Support Tensor-Train Machine (1CSTTM), an innovative framework that extends OCSVM to tensor space through Tensor Train decomposition.  This method diminishes computational and storage complexity from exponential to polynomial, facilitating scalable processing of extensive datasets.  We also introduce Randomized 1CSTTM (R1CSTTM), which utilizes random Fourier characteristics to approximate nonlinear tensorial kernels, therefore enhancing scalability and precision.  Thorough trials on actual IIoT data demonstrate that both methods exceed contemporary techniques in accuracy, efficiency, and robustness.  R1CSTTM demonstrates outstanding performance while significantly reducing training and inference durations, validating its effectiveness for large-scale anomaly detection in industrial applications.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the convergence dynamics of inflation, economic development, and exchange rates in six North African countries-Algeria, Egypt, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco, and Tunisiafrom 1980 to 2024. The analysis uses a unique econometric approach, including panel unit root tests, multivariate convergence and stability models, and Dumitrescu-Hurlin panel causality tests, to determine whether these macroeconomic variables show symptoms of convergence and dependency. The findings suggest statistically significant but diverse convergence tendencies, with better synchronization in Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, and Libya, while Egypt and Mauritania continue to diverge. Notably, the analysis finds strong bidirectional causality between inflation, exchange rates, and economic growth, underscoring inflation's critical role in regional macroeconomic interactions. Conversely, the weak causal relationship between exchange rates and growth highlights structural impediments to effective monetary transmission. These findings have significant implications for policy coordination, inflation targeting, and regional monetary integration, particularly in the context of a possible North African monetary union. The paper suggests specific convergence tactics and structural reforms to improve macroeconomic alignment and integration throughout the area.

detail.abstract: Multinational corporations (MNCs) and financial institutions frequently encounter liquidity challenges stemming from intercompany transfer restrictions, foreign exchange (FX) spreads, repatriation tax liabilities, and regulatory capital controls. These pervasive constraints lead to the phenomenon of "trapped liquidity," significantly impeding optimal capital allocation and diminishing operational efficiency. This paper introduces the Capital Efficiency Switch (CES), a comprehensive legal-financial engineering framework designed to enable internal liquidity optimization across diverse jurisdictions without breaching existing tax, FX, or regulatory boundaries. By strategically utilizing synthetic financial positions, intelligent legal entity structuring, internal hedging mechanisms, and matched domestic funding arrangements, CES creates economic equivalence to capital movement without initiating physical crossborder transfer events. The framework's practical applicability and tangible benefits are illustrated through successful implementations within Fortune 500 corporations and global financial institutions. This framework has enabled global firms to unlock over $1 billion in idle liquidity and reduce FX and tax costs by up to 40% in some jurisdictions.

detail.abstract: In this Article, we examine whether regulation is needed to protect investors in private equity. We do this by analyzing the performance of de-SPAC transactions that solicited private investment. These private investments in public equity are known as PIPEs. Because PIPE returns are publicly available, we are empirically able to determine whether the limited PIPE investors are getting a fair deal in these investments. We find that de-SPAC investors lose about forty-five percent of their investment within two years of the de-SPAC transactions. Furthermore, we find that almost all these losses are limited to those cases when the SPAC sponsors resort to PIPE financing, losing about fifty-five percent of their value abnormally. Hence, our evidence suggests that limited private-fund investors suffer substantial and systematic losses when they make PIPE investments in de-SPAC transactions. Our evidence at least partially justifies the SEC's new rules regarding the regulation of the private funds industry. Moreover, the need to address this matter has become more urgent in light of the August 7, 2025 Executive Order further opening pension funds' access to private equity markets, thus also exposing the retirement investments of retail investors to these risks.

detail.abstract:
This Chapter examines the emerging landscape of corporate climate disclosure in the Global South, focusing on Brazil, India, China, and South Africa (“BICS”), and compares the adoption of international standards by the largest economies in both the Global South and North. We analyse these early developments in view of three perspectives on Global South regulatory tendencies: (i) the resistance view, predicting opposition to climate change measures due to developmental concerns, (ii) the foreign influence view, suggesting greater susceptibility to international standards, and (iii) the legal heterodoxy view, positing that Global South jurisdictions develop legal innovations incorporating broader public policy objectives. We find diverse patterns combining elements of all three views.

Strikingly, all ten jurisdictions examined in the Global South and North have adopted some form of corporate climate disclosure in the last decade. However, following the withdrawal of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission’s defence for its climate rule in 2025, the U.S. stands out as the only major jurisdiction lacking a dedicated federal climate disclosure framework. Consistent with the foreign influence view, Brazil was the first jurisdiction worldwide to adopt ISSB standards, while China modified these standards to include double materiality. We also observe evidence of legal heterodoxy, with South Africa and India implementing pioneering frameworks for sustainability reporting that anticipated the European Union’s emphasis on double materiality.

title: Anomaly Detection in Manual Assembly Using Mmwave Sensor Data: A Deep Learning Approach with Cnn-Gru and Tfts
affiliations: Sakarya Üniversitesi, Sakarya University and University of Iowa

detail.title: Anomaly Detection in Manual Assembly Using Mmwave Sensor Data: A Deep Learning Approach with Cnn-Gru and Tfts
detail.abstract: Monitoring manual assembly processes for quality control and efficiency is critical in manufacturing. Deviations in operational timing or sequence can signal errors, operator fatigue, or inefficient workflows. This paper presents a non-invasive, intelligent monitoring system for detecting both timing and sequence anomalies in a repetitive manual assembly task using synchronized multi-modal sensors, spatio-temporal deep learning for state estimation, and advanced temporal modeling. The system integrates millimeter-wave (mmWave) radar (TI IWR6843ISK) for capturing hand motion, Time-of-Flight (ToF) sensors (VL53L0X-V2) for automated ground-truth labeling of box interactions, and optional video for debugging. A robust data collection pipeline, featuring detailed mmWave packet parsing, ensures frame-level synchronization across sensors via a centralized Frame ID generator. Raw sensor data is processed, and a CNN-GRU model is trained to estimate the current hand-box interaction state from spatio-temporal mmWave features. Subsequently, a Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT) network is developed for state sequence anomaly detection, and a statistical Z-score approach is employed for state duration anomaly detection. We demonstrate the system's ability to learn normal operational patterns from baseline data and effectively detect deliberately introduced timing and sequence anomalies. Our results highlight the potential of this combined approach—synchronized multi-modal sensing, CNN-GRU state estimation, TFTs for sequence analysis, and statistical methods for timing—for robust, real-time monitoring of manual industrial processes.

title: A Novel Reverse Virtual Sample Generation Method Via Output-Reconstructed Global-Local Cgan for Industrial Soft Sensing
affiliations: Heilongjiang University, Heilongjiang University and Heilongjiang University

detail.title: A Novel Reverse Virtual Sample Generation Method Via Output-Reconstructed Global-Local Cgan for Industrial Soft Sensing
detail.abstract: Soft sensing technology has been widely applied in predicting key quality indicators for complex industrial processes. However, the scarcity of modeling data caused by physical equipment limitations and high measurement costs severely restricts the modeling performance. To address above challenge, this paper proposes a reverse virtual sample generation (VSG) method named output-reconstructed global-local conditional generative adversarial network (ORGL-CGAN). Specifically, a decomposition-reconstruction framework is employed in ORGL-CGAN, which decomposes target output data into high-frequency and low-frequency components. During reconstruction, white noise is added to the high-frequency components to enhance sample diversity, while the low-frequency components are preserved to maintain the primary data characteristics. Furthermore, the ORGL-CGAN framework integrates a gating mechanism to fuse global features extracted via multi-head attention mechanism with local features derived from convolutional operations. This design endows the model to simultaneously handle global information processing and local detail description, thereby improving the quality of generated virtual samples. A three-dimensional numerical case and an industrial debutanizer column case are employed to validate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method. Experimental results demonstrate that ORGL-CGAN can generate high-quality virtual samples with strong distributional alignment to original data, which are beneficial for enhancing the soft sensing model performance.

title: Greasing at the Bottom of the Pyramid? The Role of Bribery, Informality, and Financial Access for African Innovators
affiliations: University of Southampton - Southampton Business School

detail.title: Greasing at the Bottom of the Pyramid? The Role of Bribery, Informality, and Financial Access for African Innovators

declarations.declarationOfInterest: No conflict of interest
declarations.funderStatement: NA

detail.abstract: The relationship between informal institutions and innovation remains poorly understood. In this study, I focus on bribery, a pervasive informal practice in many emerging markets and argue that in the African context, it exerts a positive (greasing) influence on firms' ability to introduce new product innovations. Furthermore, I propose two essential contingencies (i.e., informal competition and access to finance) that can affect this greasing effect in contrasting ways. These theoretical conjectures are tested using data on more than 10,000 firms across 37 African countries during the period 2011 to 2021. The empirical results reveal that bribery facilitates the introduction of new product innovations, with informal competition moderating negatively this relationship. Although financial accessibility stimulates directly firm innovation, it does not weaken the association between bribery and new product introductions. These findings provide novel insights into the dynamics of bribery and innovation, as well as their contextual contingencies in African markets.

title: From Relocation to Resilience: Donors’ Support for Displaced Business and Host Regions
