detail.abstract: This article aims to address this research gap and contribute to a more robust and consistent approach to the application of this remedy. It explores the functions of disgorgement and normatively suggests its ideal relationship with expectation damages through critical analysis of three potential approaches from a law and economics perspective. The most radical approach advocates for the complete replacement of expectation damages with disgorgement, ultimately proven to be infeasible primarily due to the uncertainties over the profits from breach. The second approach considers disgorgement as a generally available alternative to expectation damages. However, existing empirical evidence cannot persuasively support this over the conventional rule of using expectation damages as the primary remedy, thereby to some extent justifying the significant reluctance towards disgorgement on the positive-law level. In this sense, this article contends that the third approach is the most convincing, whereby the plaintiff is entitled to disgorgement only in specific circumstances with particular economic characteristics. Furthermore, this article provides a refined taxonomy of applicable circumstances based on varied underlying economic rationales for justifying the award of disgorgement in each category of circumstances. This taxonomy not only provides robust economic justifications for case laws and legislative provisions explicitly or implicitly endorsing contractual disgorgement across both common law (represented by English and U.S. law) and civil law (represented by German and Chinese law) jurisdictions, but also highlights how to expand the recognition of this remedy in practice.

detail.title: The State of Illinois' FY 2024 Fiscal Situation: A Solid Performance but Threats Remain

publicationDetails.detailsText: Institute of Government and Public Affairs Research Paper
publicationDetails.journalName: University of Illinois Institute of Government & Public Affairs Policy Studies Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
A new policy report provides a timely look at Illinois’ financial health and examines potential policy shifts, with a particular focus on the state’s sales tax structure. The report explores several ways in which broadening the Illinois sales tax to include the service economy would benefit state and local governments and enhance the fairness of the state’s tax code.

The report leverages an “all-funds” methodological framework to assess Illinois’ financial standing. While the analysis reveals that Illinois achieved a marginal surplus in FY 2024 (July 1,2023 through June 30, 2024), it also underscores the presence of significant headwinds that warrant careful consideration by policymakers. These challenges include the impending expiration of pandemic-era federal aid, the potential for disruptive policy shifts at the federal level and persistent fiscal pressures impacting local governments throughout Illinois. A key focal point of the spotlight is the role of sales tax revenue within Illinois’ broader fiscal framework. Sales tax revenues are a critical component of the state’s funding mechanisms, with all-funds sales tax revenue reaching $16.4 billion in FY 2024. Notably, Illinois maintains a general sales tax rate of 6.25%, which exceeds the national average.

detail.title: Assessing Accommodations for Law Students with Academic Disabilities

detail.abstract:
This Article describes the current landscape of academic disability accommodations in United States law schools, furthering the work begun in Susan Johanne Adams’s seminal article, Leveling the Floor: Classroom Accommodations for Law Students with Disabilities, 48 J. Legal Educ. 273 (1998). Since 1998, the law has evolved slowly while the percentage of academic disability accommodations in higher education has exploded. Although national averages of disabled adults have crept upwards, the percentage of students with disabilities in law school appears to be outpacing that increase by significant margins. When Adams surveyed the law school disability landscape, “academic” disabilities were a developing issue rather than the overwhelming majority of accommodations. Academic disabilities now dominate the ADA-compliance landscape in law schools.

Based in part on the first survey of ABA-accredited law schools focused onacademic disability accommodations, this Article frames the current landscape in law school higher education. Although disability accommodations in law school far outpace those of the general population, they reflect similar accommodations already granted in undergraduate institutions and by the Law School Admission Council for the LSAT. On the other hand, many state bars do not offer disability accommodations as generous as LSAC or the schools do themselves, leading to pernicious deltas between school-based expectations and licensure reality for disabled students, not to mention expectations in the practice of law. As reflected in the survey, law schools are aware of this and are concerned. This Article concludes by summarizing the key themes of the survey responses and offering some suggestions for future consideration and study.

title: A Republic If You Enforce Your Antitrust Laws Against the Dominant Digital Platform News Publishers
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: A Republic If You Enforce Your Antitrust Laws Against the Dominant Digital Platform News Publishers
detail.abstract: The dominant digital news market shares of Google and Meta pose an existential threat to the nation’s democratic system since each almost certainly possesses sufficient editorial power to determine the winner of close presidential elections through decisions about which news to promote or suppress. This threat will escalate as these companies increasingly provide genAI-generated custom news articles and videos instead of links to third-party news content. Legislative history makes clear the paramount goal of the antitrust laws is to prevent overconcentration in private industries from impairing the nation’s democracy. Because only the news industry is essential to the functioning of the democratic system, in the landmark 1945 Associated Press case the Supreme Court held that in news market antitrust cases in which liability is found the First Amendment imparts to federal courts a duty to impose remedies designed to assure sufficiently “diverse and antagonistic” news publisher competition to support a well-functioning democracy. Therefore, in the infrequent five-alarm fire instances like now when national news industry overconcentration threatens the democratic system, the enforcement agencies and the federal judiciary may eliminate the threat by enforcing existing antitrust law. Moreover, enforcing the antitrust laws to preserve a sufficiently unconcentrated news industry follows from application of standard antitrust law for differentiated product markets recognized in the Merger Guidelines. That the enforcement agencies are presently not seeking to reduce the news market shares of Google and Meta is one of the greatest abdications of law enforcement responsibility in U.S. history. In the current Google search antitrust trial, the district court should impose remedies that will with certainty reduce Google’s news market share to a non-threatening level. It may do so by imposing a news market share limitation. The Supreme Court made this principle clear in Associated Press when it held that a news publisher may not engage in unlawful anticompetitive conduct to "keep others from publishing." This principle is not surprising since it is like asserting that it does not violate the First Amendment for a court to reduce a news publisher's news market share by requiring it to return printing presses it stole from its competitors. One reason the antitrust enforcement agencies have lost sight of their paramount mission is that the Chicago school of antitrust policy advocated that federal courts ignore the congressionally mandated antitrust goal of protecting the democratic system—even in news market antitrust cases where improved democratic system functioning is a main direct intended benefit of news as a product. (Citizens consume news in part out of civic duty to make more informed voting decisions and the express mission of publishers like The New York Times and The Washington Post is to publish news to enable better informed voting decisions and policy debates.) Advocates of economics-based antitrust law should promptly help correct this antitrust policy incoherence before it leads to democratic system failure which, if it occurred, foreseeably would harm Americans by on the order of an estimated $290 trillion.

title: An Assessment of Canada’s 2021-22 Inflation Surge
affiliations: University of Miami and Federal Reserve Banks - Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis

detail.title: An Assessment of Canada’s 2021-22 Inflation Surge
detail.abstract:
• We argue that the fiscal policy responses to pandemic-induced disruptions in economic activity were primarily responsible for the 2021-22 inflation surge, and that there was little the Bank of Canada could have done to prevent it from happening.

  • Our view is based on the following premises. First, fiscal policy plays a critical role in determining both the price level and the long-run rate of inflation. Second, emergency fiscal transfers can be viewed as either funded (backed by future austerity measures) or unfunded. Unfunded fiscal transfers function as “helicopter drops” of money directly to the private sector. Whether this wealth takes the form of new money or new debt is largely irrelevant. Third, at full employment, for a given interest rate structure, injecting nominal wealth leads to a temporary burst of inflation and a permanently higher price level. Fourth, as long as inflation expectations remain anchored, central bank interest rate policy can at most influence the inflation dynamic – not the total amount of inflation ultimately realized.

  • Normally, a central bank can ignore fiscal policy, or government spending, in pursuing its mandates. However, this can change during major national emergencies – such as unexpected wars or pandemics – when large-scale fiscal expenditures are required. In these events, an unexpected increase in the price level (a short-term increase in the rate of inflation) can lower the cost of capital for financially strained firms. Interest rate policy aimed at curbing inflation in these situations may be counterproductive.

  • Viewed in this light, criticism that the Bank of Canada was slow to react to inflationary pressures may be off the mark. Given the nature of the crisis and the fiscal response, discouraging the inflation surge would have inhibited economic recovery and worsened the fiscal burden. If anything, the Bank of Canada might be criticized for not clearly communicating the trade-offs, given the likely course of fiscal policy.

keywords: Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) and Quantum-Resistant Encryption

detail.abstract: The advent of quantum computing is set to disrupt the very foundations of modern cybersecurity, rendering traditional encryption techniques vulnerable. A particularly alarming consequence of this revolution is the rise of Quantum Social Engineering, where quantum capabilities are harnessed to amplify and enhance conventional social engineering attacks. This paper explores the potential risks posed by quantum technologies in the realm of social engineering, focusing on how quantum computing can break current security mechanisms and exploit human weaknesses. By examining how quantum-powered attacks can enhance phishing, identity theft, and impersonation strategies, the paper identifies the critical need for quantum-resistant cryptographic systems, Quantum Key Distribution (QKD), and human-centered security protocols [1]. The study concludes by offering potential solutions to mitigate the emerging threats posed by Quantum Social Engineering, emphasizing the importance of preparing cybersecurity strategies for a post-quantum world.

title: Inflationary and Deflationary Pressures: A Behavioral Decomposition of U.S. Inflation Dynamics
affiliations: Universidad del Pacifico and Central Reserve Bank of Peru

detail.title: Inflationary and Deflationary Pressures: A Behavioral Decomposition of U.S. Inflation Dynamics
detail.abstract: This paper develops a novel behavioral decomposition of inflation as the net outcome of two competing forces: inflationary pressure, defined by the frequency and magnitude of price increases, and deflationary pressure, determined by corresponding price decreases. Using 245 PCE sub-indices spanning 1959-2024, we construct an exact bottom-up inflation measure that transparently maps sectoral price-setting behavior into macroeconomic aggregates. Our decomposition reveals fundamental asymmetries in inflation formation: inflationary pressure exhibits dramatic variation (2.35%-12.68%) while deflationary pressure remains remarkably stable (0.72%-5.18%), indicating inflation episodes are primarily driven by surges in upward pricing momentum rather than retreats of downward movements. Historical analysis shows distinct pressure regimes across major macroeconomic episodes: the Great Inflation featured extreme inflationary pressure volatility, the Great Moderation achieved balanced dynamics, the 2008-2009 crisis uniquely witnessed deflationary pressure dominance creating deflation risk, while COVID-19 saw dramatic inflationary pressure resurgence. We reassess the price puzzle using Bayesian local projections with alternative monetary policy shock identifications. Conventional narrative shocks generate sustained inflationary pressure increases with minimal deflationary response, while informationally robust shocks resolve the puzzle completely through both increased deflationary pressure and reduced inflationary pressure, with the deflationary channel providing the dominant contribution consistent with demand-channel transmission. Extensive robustness checks across specifications and estimation methods confirm these findings while revealing the diagnostic value of pressure decomposition for evaluating shock quality. Results demonstrate that the price puzzle reflects informational frictions rather than genuine economic phenomena, and suggest successful monetary policy operates through managing pressure balance with important implications for real-time policy diagnosis and central bank communication.

This paper introduces BankSwitch.ai, an AI-powered platform designed to analyze, recommend, and seamlessly migrate users to better financial products in real-time. This paper includes empirical evidence, model comparisons, regional market opportunities, and ethical considerations to promote the adoption of behavior-first credit frameworks across the auto finance sector.

title: Poverty, Food Insecurity and Malnutrition in Sub-Saharan Africa
affiliations: GIGA - Hamburg, Institute of African Affairs

detail.title: Poverty, Food Insecurity and Malnutrition in Sub-Saharan Africa
detail.abstract: ABSTRACT & RÉSUMÉ & ZUSAMMENFASSUNG: In the 21st century, Africa has some of the highest levels of hunger and malnutrition in the world, which is incompatible with the vision of the African Union. Food and nutritional security is a fundamental right of every person. However, many Africans are deprived of this right. Reports by the FAO and WFP indicate the emergence of an acute food crisis in at least 27 countries. This crisis has escaped the attention of the general press and the political sphere in the West. Yet this is crucial for understanding the reasons behind current migration flows, as well as for stimulating the necessary solidarity interventions. Poverty and malnutrition result from uncontrolled rapid population growth, inefficient agricultural and industrial practices, the high debt profiles of many African countries due to poor governance and corruption, and diseases such as the AIDS epidemic, malaria, the Ebola virus and the current pandemic of the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Other factors include poor and inadequate health infrastructure and armed conflicts. Despite an abundance of natural resources, the gross domestic product per capita of many African countries is among the lowest in the world. According to FAO data, over 200 million people in sub-Saharan Africa were undernourished between 2014 and 2016. The prevalence of undernourishment in sub-Saharan Africa increased from 181 million people in 2010 to 222 million in 2016. In 2016, Africa had the highest prevalence of undernourishment in the world, estimated at 20% of the population. Poverty is the main cause of hunger and malnutrition in Africa, while hunger and malnutrition exacerbate the problem of disease on the continent. Poverty continues to plague Africa as a result of poor economic policies, conflict, war, environmental factors such as drought and climate change, population growth, poor leadership and greed. This situation is further exacerbated by the vicious cycle of poverty, disease and illness. Whether directly or indirectly, due to inadequate food consumption and poor diet quality, it is also accountable for over half of all deaths among children in Sub-Saharan Africa. Sociocultural barriers are major hindrances in some communities, with female children usually being the most affected. Corruption and lack of government interest and investment are key players that must be addressed to solve this problem. Malnutrition was highest within countries in East Africa and West Africa compared to the WHO Millennium development goals target for 2015. The system dynamics simulations forecast a rather gloomy future for the agro-food sector in SSA. Even the historically highest development rate of agricultural production will not be enough to meet the rapidly increasing demand for food. --

title: Climate Extrapolation and Relative Asset Pricing: Evidence from Bordeaux Premier Cru Wine Auctions
affiliations: University of Auckland - Department of Accounting and Finance

detail.title: Climate Extrapolation and Relative Asset Pricing: Evidence from Bordeaux Premier Cru Wine Auctions
detail.abstract: This paper offers evidence for climate extrapolation, a behavioral tendency where economic agents project salient local climate risks onto an asset's valuation. Using a new dataset of over 68,000 Bordeaux Premier Cru auction prices from 222 houses across 17 countries, we highlight that greater relative climate attention in a foreign country leads to 3.58% lower relative prices for the identical bottle sold in the same month. This is consistent with the availability heuristic and is concentrated among wines of lower perceived quality (a concern for investors) and closer to the end of their drinking period (a concern for consumers). The findings cannot be explained by natural disasters, economic uncertainty, sentiment, selection bias, and granular lot-level differences in bottle conditions.

detail.abstract: Access to credit remains one of the most persistent barriers to economic mobility, particularly among subprime borrowers and underserved communities. This paper introduces 'Community Boost', a platform-agnostic, patentable social financing model that leverages trust-based peer support to reduce borrower risk and enhance loan approval rates. By combining financial contributions from friends, family, or community members with behavioral underwriting and dynamic risk-sharing, the model unlocks new pathways to inclusive credit. We present the platform's architecture, evaluate its social and financial impact, and demonstrate how this innovation may reshape lending ecosystems at scale. Diagrams, formulas, and implementation roadmaps are provided to guide future research and real-world application.

title: CSR and Exposure to Systemic Risk: Building Resilience in Non-Financial Firms
affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Delhi and Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Delhi - Department of Management Studies

detail.title: CSR and Exposure to Systemic Risk: Building Resilience in Non-Financial Firms
detail.abstract: By using a sample of non-financial listed Indian firms, we find that firms that spend more funds on Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) observe a greater reduction in their exposure to systemic risk. The negative relationship between CSR spending and systemic risk persists even during the global financial crisis and COVID-19 pandemic periods. It is more pronounced for firms that are mandated to spend on CSR than those which are not. CSR reduces the exposure to systemic risk by improving the information quality, reducing the probability of default, and enhancing the firm valuation. Our study highlights the importance of integrating CSR into the policymaking, which is directed towards mitigating the systemic risk. It in turn would ensure financial stability and reduce crises in an economy.

title: Socially Optimal Ex-ante Adjudication
affiliations: The University of Sydney - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Socially Optimal Ex-ante Adjudication

declarations.funderStatement: The Australian Research Council partially funded the research through a Discovery Early Career Researcher Award (DECRA). Grant number: DE230100557

detail.abstract:
Ex-ante adjudication prospectively ascertains the legality of some proposed conduct. This article studies ex-ante adjudication using a signaling model. An actor may take an action that benefits herself but produces an externality to others. This action attracts a risk of ex-post adjudication and sanction. The actor seeks ex-ante adjudication before deciding how to act. Conducting ex-ante adjudication, a socially-minded judge decides how accurately to ascertain whether the proposed action is sanctionable.

In equilibrium, ex-ante adjudication is never fully accurate. When the threat of ex-post adjudication and sanction fails to incentivize socially desirable conduct, the judge conducting ex-ante adjudication can occasionally make erroneous rulings to encourage such conduct. She cannot err too often, otherwise her rulings will not be followed. As the quality of ex-post adjudication or sanction worsens, surprisingly, equilibrium ex-ante adjudication must more accurately mimic ex-post adjudication; otherwise, erroneous but socially beneficial ex-ante rulings will not be followed.

These results partially explain and justify the discretionary nature of ex-ante adjudication in reality. These results are also consistent with how ex-ante adjudication is conducted regarding trusts, insurance, patent validity, and international law. These results further offer normative guidance for the design and conduct of ex-ante adjudication more generally.

title: An Organizational Law Theory of Stablecoins
affiliations: The University of Hong Kong - Faculty of Law

detail.title: An Organizational Law Theory of Stablecoins
detail.abstract:
In recent years, many jurisdictions have begun developing laws to govern stablecoins. There is an ongoing debate about whether stablecoin should be regulated as banks, money market funds, or securities. This article develops an organizational law theory of stablecoins, arguing that their defining feature is managerial ownership of liquid funds—a structure that distinguishes them from both money market funds and bank deposits. It reframes the regulatory challenges associated with stablecoins as resulting from the conflicts of interest between the shareholders of the stablecoin operators and the stablecoin holders as consumers. This theory explains the rationale behind key regulatory measures—such as investment restrictions, overcollateralization requirements, priority claims, and resolution mechanisms—adopted by regulators in several major jurisdictions.

This article suggests that defining stablecoins based on their organizational structure offers a more effective framework for regulating financial products with both similar and divergent features, including various types of e-payment platforms operating on centralized or decentralized ledgers. The theory also sheds important light on the limitations of bankruptcy remoteness of the reserve assets, particularly when protecting stablecoin holders conflicts with the interests of other creditors of the issuing entity. Drawing on the asset partitioning theory, this article identifies two critical factors that regulators should consider in whether to respect the bankruptcy remoteness of the reserve assets: the presence of nonadjusting creditors and other business risks associated with the stablecoin operators. Finally, the organizational law theory offers a theoretical foundation for cross-jurisdictional comparisons, enabling regulators to better evaluate and learn from each other’s approaches to stablecoin regulation.

title: Resilient Value Economy 2.0: A Motivation‑Aligned Universal Basic Income with State‑Level Talent Investment

detail.abstract: The Resilient Value Economy (RVE) 2.0 is a Universal Basic Income (UBI) architecture that guarantees biological and social survival-not comfort or status-while keeping upward mobility tied to work, learning, entrepreneurship, and risk-taking. A broad employer-side base tax finances a nationally coordinated UBI transparently benchmarked to a published "essentials basket" (food, housing, clothing, medical care, transport, telecom). State governments invest in people to keep their populations competitive in the national labor market, aligning public services, education, and reskilling with measurable outcomes. RVE 2.0 formalizes an accountability triangle-citizens ↔ governments ↔ employers-with clear cost dashboards, versioned budgets, and feedback loops. By separating survival from coercion, the model aims to reduce poverty-driven fear, increase productive risk-taking, and stabilize transitions (automation, recessions, migration). Version 2.0 sharpens: (i) the fiscal plumbing (employer base tax + national transfer + state-level investment mandates), (ii) the governance blueprint (transparent menus, versioned releases, metrics), and (iii) incentive compatibility (no benefit cliffs; motivation through ambition, not desperation).

title: Making Growth Theory Relevant: Connecting Capital-Labor Augmentation, Theory And Empirical Research, And Economics And Nature
affiliations: Brandeis University - International Business School

detail.title: Making Growth Theory Relevant: Connecting Capital-Labor Augmentation, Theory And Empirical Research, And Economics And Nature
detail.abstract: This paper addresses the problem of modern growth theory being theoretically and empirically invalid, divorced from empirical research, and lacking a consensus theoretical core. The problem embeds in Samuelson's axiomatic principle-the "factual assumption" that natural units of capital designated as unaugmentable dollars that only accumulate and labor as workers that primarily augment frames the tautological result that "requires technical change to be labor augmenting, and nothing else," thereby precluding readily-observable technology-augmenting capital investment. Our theoretical frame uncovers the "inside anatomy" of technology and growth by specifying Four Levels of Augmentation: A) Households and firms functioning as platforms for augmentation, optimizing and translating new technologies into growth; B) The brain and machine subsystems serving as the loci of recombinant processing, transforming oldto-new ideas and objects; C) Neural networks and molecular compounds, the "natural units," remixed by brains and machines to augment the A-Level host production factors; and D) Human and physical capital investment animating the (A,B,C) physical processes of augmentation. A foundational principle of recombinant innovation emerges; that is, while conventional theory represents gL and gAL as perfect growth substitutes with gK functioning alone, recombinant innovation requires that factor accumulation and augmentation of physical matter be inseparable-gAL requires gL; gK induces gAK. Hence, the steady-state equation transforms from K ̇=sY to ȦKK=sY and the Harrod function, Y=F(K,AL), to Y=F(AKK,ALL). Consistent with Laibson's assertion that economics need engage with the natural sciences, the paper recognizes the consequential role of nature's physical endowment and its ubiquitous laws in framing modern technical change.

title: Policy Risk and Financial Markets: Evidence From 1930s China
affiliations: The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) and Peking University - School of Economics

detail.title: Policy Risk and Financial Markets: Evidence From 1930s China
detail.abstract: How does policy risk affect financial markets? To investigate this question, we study the 1930s Chinese silver crisis and construct a novel dataset of high-frequency financial data and newspaper sentiment data. We show that U.S. silver purchases propelled financial events in China, but not in the ways commonly described by the extant literature. Specifically, we argue that China's silver policy risk triggered massive silver outflows that induced a severe credit crunch and further weakened the government's perceived commitment to the silver standard. In turn, such weakened perceived commitment made the silver standard unsustainable. Notably, a contemporaneous comparison with Hong Kong reveals that rising global silver prices did not cause persistent silver outflows or a credit crunch in the absence of silver policy risk. These findings underscore the crucial role of policy risk in shaping economic outcomes in developing economies.

title: Leveraging Natural Resources for Economic Growth: An Analysis of Resource Utilization and Development Strategies in Mozambique
affiliations: University of Leeds

detail.title: Leveraging Natural Resources for Economic Growth: An Analysis of Resource Utilization and Development Strategies in Mozambique
detail.abstract: Mozambique is endowed with abundant natural resources, including vast reserves of natural gas, coal, and valuable minerals. These assets have the potential to drive significant economic growth and development. However, despite a decade of resource-driven investments and export growth, the broader socioeconomic impact has remained limited. This study critically examines the role of natural resources in Mozambique's development trajectory, with a focus on how they have been utilized and governed, and what strategies can enhance their contribution to inclusive and sustainable growth. The research adopts a qualitative, case study methodology based on secondary data from government reports, international organizations, academic literature, and policy analyses. Using a political economy framework, the study explores four key dimensions: the structure of the extractive sector, governance and institutions, socioeconomic outcomes, and policy effectiveness. Findings reveal that while extractive industries have increased export earnings and attracted foreign investment, they have failed to generate broad-based benefits for the population. Weak institutions, governance deficits, regional inequalities, and poor implementation of local content and environmental regulations have undermined the developmental potential of resource wealth. The study also highlights the risks of overdependence on fossil fuel exports in the context of global energy transitions and climate change. The article concludes that Mozambique's natural resources can support long-term economic transformation only if supported by transparent governance, institutional reform, economic diversification, and inclusive development policies. It offers policy recommendations focused on strengthening governance, promoting value addition, empowering local communities, and ensuring environmental sustainability. These insights contribute to the broader discourse on the challenges and opportunities of resource-led development in low-income, resource-rich countries.

Such is the case for Coinbase Global, Inc., now a major factor in the phenomenal growth of the cryptocurrency ecosystem worldwide. Professors Trautman, Elzweig, and Newman teach that "Disclosures required to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)-such as annual, quarterly, and notice of materially significant events-are a particularly valuable source of information for those engaged in business strategy." As global cryptocurrency markets continue to grow with the adoption of stablecoins and other crypto asset legislation in the United States during 2025, we appear to have entered a new dawn of electronic crypto currencies and funds transfer.

title: Exploring Australian Parent Preferences for a School-Provided Meal Offering Using a Discrete Choice Experiment
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Flinders University, Deakin University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Exploring Australian Parent Preferences for a School-Provided Meal Offering Using a Discrete Choice Experiment
detail.abstract: There is growing interest in school-provided meal offerings in Australia. As a key stakeholder, it is important to understand Australian parent/caregiver preferences for such an offering. This study aimed to investigate parent interest and preferences in a school-provided meal offering for Australian primary schools. An online survey incorporating a discrete choice experiment was administered to parents of primary school-aged children across Australia. The discrete choice experiment involved 12 choice tasks, where parents were required to choose between two hypothetical school-provided lunch offerings. Six attributes with varying levels were used to describe the choice options: cost, nutrition and quality, environmental sustainability, access, menu options, and the school approach to food. A d-efficient design was constructed, with data analysed using multinomial logit models and the Krinsky and Robb method to calculate willingness to pay. The final sample consisted of 383 participants, predominantly women (90%). A majority expressed interest in school-provided meals (93%). The most significant influence on parent choice was nutrition and quality (β=0.71), followed by menu options (β=0.47), environmental sustainability (β=0.35), and a whole-school approach to food (β=0.28). A negative cost coefficient indicated a preference for lower-cost options. Parents were willing to pay for enhancements, indicating the attributes were financially valued by parents. Results demonstrate Australian parent support for comprehensively designed and delivered school-provided lunches, aligned with their preferences. Parental preferences should be considered in system design, alongside other stakeholder perspectives, to achieve an acceptable and financially equitable school-provided meal system in Australia.

title: Human Capital in a Time of Low Real Rates
affiliations: Duke University - Fuqua School of Business and Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago

detail.title: Human Capital in a Time of Low Real Rates

publicationDetails.detailsText: FRB of Chicago Working Paper No. 2025-15
publicationDetails.journalName: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: We argue that a long-term low real rate environment can increase labor income inequality, amplify the emergence of the working rich, and reduce intergenerational mobility. We provide a simple model with endogenous human capital accumulation and credit constraints to demonstrate this causal link. The mechanism operates through a tilting of the human capital gradient: wealthy households, more so than poor households, will increase human capital investment in response to low rates. Normatively, these tilting responses to low rates are inefficient, but higher capital taxes are not an ideal response. We find empirical support for our tilting mechanism over the last 60 years in the U.S. Quantitatively, we show that the endogenous human capital investment response to low interest rates can account for a 17% rise in cross-sectional labor income variance (higher inequality) and a 7% higher parent-child labor income intergenerational elasticity (lower mobility).

title: Quantifying the Impacts of Weather Year Selection on Power Sector Capacity Expansion Models
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Texas at Austin and University of Texas at Austin

detail.title: Quantifying the Impacts of Weather Year Selection on Power Sector Capacity Expansion Models
detail.abstract: Power system capacity expansion models (CEMS)  inform optimal investment in the electricity grid but are dependent on assumptions about the future grid, including hourly electricity demand shapes and renewable availability profiles. Modelers often base these profiles on a single year of data. Because weather impacts generation performance and electricity demand, it is important to ensure CEMs use same-year load and renewable energy production profiles. However, the user is often left to decide which base year to use. Because different years have different load and renewable energy shapes, future projections based on any particular year might yield different optimal futures. The purpose of this study is to test that assumption and assess the impact of the baseline weather year selection on investment decisions made by CEMs for future generation development. We ran twenty CEM simulations of ERCOT from 2022-2050, each with a distinct base weather year from 2002-2021. We find negligible variation with weather year for the bulk grid-wide capacity and energy results, but found that variations in regional capacity, total costs, and emissions were more significant. While these deviations might be tolerable for many projects, we conclude that utilizing multiple weather years will improve model accuracy. Our results indicate that the share of electricity generated by variable sources is consistent across weather years, although the specific mix exhibits noticeable variation. We discover that the precision of simulations with multiple temporal stages can be improved without additional computational cost by utilizing data from a separate weather year during each model period.

title: Capital Tax Competition and Inequality
affiliations: University of Chicago - Becker Friedman Institute for Economics

detail.title: Capital Tax Competition and Inequality
detail.abstract: Rising inequality across much of the developed world has renewed calls to tax those with the ``broadest shoulders'', but critics counter that ``those with the broadest shoulders often have the niftiest feet'', citing the ease with which capital moves across borders. I develop a multi-country dynamic incomplete markets model in which capital is internationally mobile, governments engage in non-cooperative capital tax competition, and households differ in physical and human capital holdings. Domestic inequality amplifies ``race-to-the-bottom'' dynamics in the short run, but long-run savings responses temper them. A quantitative EU application shows persistent cross-country differences hinder efforts to coordinate tax policies.

title: Strategy Implementation in Family Firms: Why it Matters and How it Differs
affiliations: University of North Carolina (UNC) at Charlotte, Lucerne University of Applied Sciences and Arts, Jonkoping University - Jonkoping International Business School (JIBS), Macquarie University, Macquarie Business School and Jonkoping University - Jonkoping International Business School (JIBS)

detail.title: Strategy Implementation in Family Firms: Why it Matters and How it Differs
detail.abstract: Implementing strategy is rarely straightforward. For family firms, it is even more complex due to their blend of business logic and family dynamics. While this complexity may seem like a liability, it can become a source of strategic advantage in unpredictable environments where adaptability is key. Yet not all family firms are the same. This article explores how differences in ownership structure, generational involvement, family dynamics, financial and nonfinancial objectives, family involvement in management, and governance maturity enable some family firms to effectively implement adaptive strategy. Drawing on real-world examples, we show how certain family enterprises turn their complexity into a strength by cultivating a shared sense of orientation, resilience, and agility. In doing so, we offer a practitioner-oriented roadmap for implementing strategy in today's uncertain world.

title: Market-Based Short-Rate Uncertainty and Time-Varying Expected Returns
affiliations: College of Finance and Statistics, Hunan University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and College of Finance and Statistics, Hunan University

detail.title: Market-Based Short-Rate Uncertainty and Time-Varying Expected Returns
detail.abstract: This paper establishes that the cyclical component of market-based short-term interest rate uncertainty (SRU) serves as a robust predictor of aggregate market excess returns, whereas its slow-moving component obscures this predictive ability. In real-time forecasting, the cyclical SRU achieves an out-of-sample R2 of up to 14.22%, outperforming both a constant expected return model and a range of widely used macroeconomic and financial predictors. Furthermore, it delivers substantial economic value for mean-variance investors, enhancing utility gains and Sharpe ratios. The cyclical component exhibits stronger linkages to interest rates, economic activities, and investor sentiment compared to the slow-moving component, which accounts for its superior predictive performance. Within the present-value framework, we demonstrate that the predictive power of SRU primarily stems from its ability to forecast future cash flows.

title: An Empirical Evaluation of Machine Learning Classifiers for Credit Risk in Peer-to-Peer Lending
affiliations: Ulster University, Balikesir University and Adiyaman University

detail.title: An Empirical Evaluation of Machine Learning Classifiers for Credit Risk in Peer-to-Peer Lending
detail.abstract: This paper provides an empirical evaluation of machine learning (ML) classifiers for credit default prediction in peer-to-peer lending. We contribute to the literature on applied risk assessment and model governance in financial intermediation. Seven supervised learning ML algorithms are benchmarked in terms of predictive performance, interpretability, and computational feasibility. Gradient boosting methods achieve the highest AUC-ROC scores (>0.69), but their opacity limits practical deployment under regulatory constraints. We demonstrate a trade-off between classification accuracy and transparency, a concern of growing importance to financial institutions. Using formal statistical tests, we assess whether differences in performance across models are significant. Our results offer insights for peer-to-peer fintech lenders and can be extended to banks and regulators deploying ML for credit risk assessment. Our findings inform financial decision-making by clarifying the trade-offs involved in selecting scoring models.

title: Rohingya Refugee Camps and Land Cover Change in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh
affiliations: University of Victoria - Economics, University of Minnesota and University of Minnesota - St. Paul - Institute on the Environment

detail.title: Rohingya Refugee Camps and Land Cover Change in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh
detail.abstract: How do refugee camps impact local land cover in contexts of high population density and limited land availability? We explore this question in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh using 30m resolution bespoke land cover classification data. Our analysis focuses on impacts in areas 0-5 km from camps. The identification strategy relies on differencein-difference (DID) two-way fixed effects specifications exploiting the 2017 mass displacement event and resulting encampment expansion. Specifically, we estimate outcomes using areas 10-15 km from camp boundaries as the control group, and we also use propensity score matching on pre-treatment forest and settlement cover in combination with a DID specification. We explore the parallel trends assumption further using the HonestDID approach. Within the local area 0-5 km outside of camps, forest cover falls by 7-8 percentage points (ppt) after camp openings and settlement cover increases by 10-11 ppt. Heterogeneity analysis reveals no significant impacts of camp opening on nearby protected areas. A robustness check using the Global Land Cover 30m resolution data supports our main findings but yields smaller coefficient estimates due to greater random error in a globally calibrated product.

title: Assessing Public Perception and Compensation for Wind Power Externalities in Rural Northeast China
affiliations: Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing Institute of Technology, Institutes of Science and Development, Chinese Academy of Sciences and Peking University

detail.title: Assessing Public Perception and Compensation for Wind Power Externalities in Rural Northeast China
detail.abstract: The rapid deployment of wind energy, while driving energy transition, is accompanied by significant negative externalities, primarily including noise pollution, visual landscape intrusion, and ecosystem disruption. These impacts disturb local residents and have triggered public complaints to wind power projects. However, research on the negative externalities of wind power and their associated costs remains scarce in China. To address this gap, this study employs the Contingent Valuation Method to quantify wind energy externalities and their costs through a survey of 185 residents near the Changgao Wind Farm in Northeast China. We reveal that noise is the most pronounced externality, showing a distance-dependent attenuation pattern: 75% of residents within 600 meters of wind turbines report moderate-to-significant noise, decreasing to 58% between 600 and 1,000 meters, and 54% between 1,000 and 1,500 meters. Beyond 1,500 meters, no significant noise is heard, and 71% report negligible impact. Other notable externalities include landscape changes, shadow flicker, concerns about turbine accidents, precipitation impact uncertainties, and unpleasant odors. Positive perceptions include an increased power supply and environmental benefits. The median willingness to pay (WTP) to prevent construction is 4.0 CNY/month/household, and the willingness to accept (WTA) compensation is 9.6 CNY/month/household. Factors such as age, household size, noise perception, landscape changes, safety concerns, land compensation, and perceived benefits significantly influence WTP/WTA values. These empirical results provide valuable insights for establishing science-based buffer zones and equitable compensation mechanisms in China's wind energy development.

title: Do Investors Buy Innovation: Market Responses to Ethereum Development Milestones
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Bucharest University of Economic Studies, Business School, Sun Yat-Sen University and Bucharest University of Economic Studies

detail.title: Do Investors Buy Innovation: Market Responses to Ethereum Development Milestones
detail.abstract: Ethereum has undergone a series of protocol upgrades that are publicly announced yet technically complex, raising a key question: Do markets fully incorporate these innovations into prices? This paper explores investor responses to Ethereum Improvement Proposals (EIPs), emphasizing the role of informational asymmetries and herding behavior in cryptocurrency (crypto) asset pricing. Our findings provide evidence supporting both the "innovation-growth'' and the "innovation-fragility'' hypotheses. Specifically, security- and validator-related upgrades are associated with positive returns and increased volatility, while monetary upgrades tend to dampen volatility. When upgrades are considered significant for the entire crypto ecosystem, their effects would spill over into other crypto markets. These findings offer new insights into how innovation is priced in decentralized markets and provide implications in asset decision for the broader crypto-asset ecosystem.

title: Estpsr: An Efficient Gan-Based Framework for Enhanced Structure and Texture-Preserving Super-Resolution
affiliations: IIT Delhi, National Institute of Technology Silchar and National Institute of Technology Silchar

detail.title: Estpsr: An Efficient Gan-Based Framework for Enhanced Structure and Texture-Preserving Super-Resolution
detail.abstract: In the realm of Single Image Super-Resolution (SISR), Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) have driven significant advancements. However, achieving high perceptual quality while preserving crucial structural details remains a challenge, often at the expense of computational efficiency. To address these issues, we introduce ESTPSR, an efficient GAN-based framework specifically designed for enhanced structure and texture reconstruction. ESTPSR incorporates Attentionguided Mixed Dilated Residual Blocks (AMDRBs), which efficiently extract both local and global features by combining standard and dilated convolutions with the parameter-free SimAM attention mechanism. Additionally, its gradient-guided branch generates high-resolution gradient maps that serve as structural priors, guiding the super-resolution process. To improve training stability and perceptual quality, a Residual Relativistic average Patch Discriminator (RRPD) is developed that evaluates patch-wise relative authenticity, leveraging residual connections. Compared to the baseline SRGAN model, ESTPSR achieves up to +0.84dB gain in PSNR, a 36% reduction in LPIPS, and a 12% improvement in Perceptual Index (PI) on the Set14 dataset. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that ESTPSR achieves superior performance in both quantitative and perceptual evaluations, while maintaining a significantly lower parameter count (1.35M) compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: Spalign: Structure-Aware Smooth Perception for Heterogeneous Feature Alignment in Personalized Federated Learning
affiliations: Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan University of Science and Technology and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Spalign: Structure-Aware Smooth Perception for Heterogeneous Feature Alignment in Personalized Federated Learning
detail.abstract: Personalized Federated Learning (PFL) addresses non-IID data heterogeneity by tailoring models to client-specific distributions. However, existing PFL methods exhibit two fundamental limitations:  (1) Intra-client feature structural inconsistency: Local models generate dispersed intra-class representations and entangled inter-class boundaries due to biased feature distributions, compromising feature discriminability; (2) Inter-client representational misalignment: Divergent feature scales across clients necessitate heavy hyperparameter tuning, hindering knowledge transfer. To overcome these challenges, we propose a new PFL framework, termed SPAlign, which uses structure-aware smooth perception for heterogeneous feature alignment. Specifically, SPAlign integrates: Intra-client structure rectification: Exponential Moving Average (EMA) with intra-class standardization yields perceptual logit, enhancing intra-class compactness; Inter-client representation alignment: Unified statistical space mapping reduces τ-sensitivity by >30% and eliminates cross-client scale discrepancies. Under guidance from historical personalized models, SPAlign optimizes distillation to harmonize client adaptation and global consistency. Extensive experimental results on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 demonstrate the superiority and effectiveness of SPAlign over existing state-of-the-arts. Notably, SPAlign exhibits enhanced robustness and personalization, especially under highly heterogeneous data distributions and large-scale client settings.

title: Edge-Aware Sar Ship Detection: Multi-Scale Edge-Semantic Fusion and Contrast-Driven Feature Aggregation
affiliations: Nankai University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Nankai University

detail.title: Edge-Aware Sar Ship Detection: Multi-Scale Edge-Semantic Fusion and Contrast-Driven Feature Aggregation
detail.abstract: Accurate target localization in Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) ship detection is critically dependent on the availability of robust edge information. However, conventional detection networks typically lack explicit mechanisms for enhancing edge feature awareness. To address this shortcoming, we propose a Multi-Scale Edge-Semantic Fusion (MEF) module that extracts edge features from shallow convolutional layers and propagates them through the backbone network, enabling multiscale edge semantic fusion. The linear edge features of ships naturally align with the step-like basis functions of Haarwavelets.BycombiningwiththeContrast-DrivenFeatureAggregation(CDFA)module,theedge detection and feature extraction effects are enhanced through multiscale spectral analysis and attention mechanisms. We conducted extensive experiments on multiple datasets, achieving consistent gains across various mainstream architectures. The enhanced RT-DETR model achieved a 4.1% increase in mAP, and the enhanced YOLO11 achieves state-of-the-art accuracy. This work bridges the gap between edge feature extraction and deep semantic fusion, with the detailed implementation open sourced at https://github.com/ZJ-Song-Lab/MEF-CDFA.

title: Strategic Cryptocurrency Disclosures and Insider Trading
affiliations: University of Bristol and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Strategic Cryptocurrency Disclosures and Insider Trading
detail.abstract: This study investigates whether managers strategically disclose cryptocurrency-related information in 10-K filings to pursue personal financial gains. Using generative AI models, we identify speculative cryptocurrency disclosures made by firms without substantive crypto involvement. We find that insiders are significantly more likely to purchase shares prior to such disclosures, earning higher abnormal returns and trading in greater volume. These trades are more likely to be opportunistic, particularly when disclosures are highly informative, placed in Item 1 of the 10-K, or issued during periods of elevated cryptocurrency market sentiment. We also find that repeated speculative disclosures amplify investor misperception and further enhance insider profitability. Our results suggest that managers exploit investor enthusiasm for cryptocurrencies by strategically timing disclosures and insider trades, even in the absence of real crypto activity. Our findings provide novel insights into the opportunistic motivations driving strategic cryptocurrency disclosures and raise concerns about managerial opportunism and market misinterpretation.

title: An Empirical Analysis of Conference-Driven Return Drift in Tech Stocks
affiliations: Quantpedia and Quantpedia

detail.title: An Empirical Analysis of Conference-Driven Return Drift in Tech Stocks

declarations.declarationOfInterest: ☒ The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

detail.abstract: Corporate conferences have long been recognized as pivotal events in financial markets, serving as catalysts that signal upcoming innovations and strategic shifts. Scheduled corporate events induce market reactions that can be systematically analyzed to reveal predictable return patterns. In this work, we focus on examining the return drift exhibited by technology stocks in the days surrounding their respective conferences, employing simple quantitative methods with daily price data. The hypothesized return drift is premised on the notion that investor sentiment and market dynamics are significantly altered by the information disseminated at these conferences. Investors, reacting to both anticipatory signals and post-announcement adjustments, tend to drive prices in a measurable manner in the windows immediately preceding, during, and after the events. By systematically analyzing stocks of companies such as Apple, Google, and Microsoft, this study aims to validate the existence of these drift patterns and shed light on the underlying mechanisms, thereby enhancing mutual understanding of event-driven asset pricing dynamics.

title: National Directors’ Foreign Corporate Board Experience and Foreign Investments
affiliations: emlyon business school, Kedge Business School Bordeaux and University of Groningen

detail.title: National Directors’ Foreign Corporate Board Experience and Foreign Investments
detail.abstract: Employing a sample of 4,053 US-headquartered listed firms, we show that firms with U.S. directors who have experience in code law countries reduce foreign investments. This negative association is particularly strong for non-executive US directors with past foreign board experience as opposed to executive directors, who are typically responsible for setting corporate policies. Additional analysis suggests that firms with such directors exhibit lower levels of operational risk-taking and adopt conservative corporate policies, such as increased payouts through stock repurchases. These results suggest that national directors with experience in foreign institutional environments—specifically, code law systems, negatively influence foreign investment at home.

title: Structural Tax: Tier-1 Systemic Deployment of the Four Affordances
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Structural Tax: Tier-1 Systemic Deployment of the Four Affordances
detail.abstract: This paper presents the first-tier systemic deployment of Structural Tax by introducing four modular governance affordances-Atomic Layered Economic Topography, Universal Transaction Node Viewer, Structural Topology Integrity Module, and Directional Compass for Structural Navigation. These affordances translate the theory's geometric topology into real-time fiscal governance, ensuring transparent node-level feedback, parameter lock-in, and policy directionality without reliance on identity, sector, or narrative. All definitions, parameters, and logics are derived solely from the author's prior unpublished manuscripts on Structural Tax and Structural Price Equation. No external theoretical references are required.

title: “Centre Bias” is Lower in More Unequal Local Contexts
affiliations: University of Konstanz and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: “Centre Bias” is Lower in More Unequal Local Contexts
detail.abstract: We examine the relationship between local income inequality / local income levels and people’s misconception that they are in the middle of the national income distribution (“center bias”). Local contexts shape perceptions of inequality by influencing the availability of opportunities for upward and downward social comparisons. Four mechanisms could link local inequality levels to perceptions of one’s relative income position: exposure versus segregation and contrast versus assimilation. We supplement geo-referenced survey data with context information and show that higher local inequality is associated with lower “center bias” (“exposure” mechanism). However, respondents feel richer in richer contexts only by tendency (“assimilation” mechanism).

title: Image Complexity Representation Via Content Invariance Contrastive Learning
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Image Complexity Representation Via Content Invariance Contrastive Learning
detail.abstract: Unsupervised image complexity representation often suffers from bias in positive sample selection and sensitivity to image content. We propose CLICv2, a contrastive learning framework that enforces content invariance for complexity representation. Unlike CLIC, which generates positive samples via cropping—introducing positive pairs bias—our shifted patchify method applies randomized directional shifts to image patches before contrastive learning. Patches at corresponding positions serve as positive pairs, ensuring content-invariant learning. Additionally, we propose patch-wise contrastive loss, which enhances local complexity representation while mitigating content interference. In order to further suppress the interference of image content, we introduce Masked Image Modeling as an auxiliary task, but we set its modeling objective as the entropy of masked patches, which recovers the entropy of the overall image by using the information of the unmasked patches, and then obtains the global complexity perception ability. Extensive experiments on IC9600 demonstrate that CLICv2 significantly outperforms existing unsupervised methods in PCC and SRCC, achieving content-invariant complexity representation without introducing positive pairs bias.

title: Electricity Spot Market Reform and Overcapacity in Fossil-Fired Power Firms: A Quasi-Natural Experiment Based on China Power Market
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Xi'an Jiaotong University (XJTU) - School of Management

detail.title: Electricity Spot Market Reform and Overcapacity in Fossil-Fired Power Firms: A Quasi-Natural Experiment Based on China Power Market
detail.abstract: This study examines the impact of China’s electricity spot market reform on overcapacity among fossil-fired power firms. By introducing real-time pricing mechanisms and enhancing market competition, the reform has led to severe capacity idleness among coal-fired power producers in the absence of policy support. Empirical evidence shows that the reform has exacerbated overcapacity in several provinces, with more pronounced effects in regions with higher levels of market liberalization. The analysis identifies environmental regulation stringency and firms’ financial trading capacity as key factors influencing capacity adjustment, while interregional power transmission plays a mitigating role. This paper introduces and conceptualizes the phenomenon of “passive idleness” as a novel form of overcapacity, contributing to the theoretical understanding of electricity market reform. The findings offer important policy implications, highlighting the need to balance market efficiency with institutional equity in the ongoing transition toward a more market-oriented power sector.

title: The Impact of AI on Competition Across Business Functions
affiliations: Desautels Faculty of Management, McGill University and USC Gould School of Law

detail.title: The Impact of AI on Competition Across Business Functions
detail.abstract: AI, and especially generative AI, is fundamentally reshaping competition across business functions. This article highlights its impact on marketing, operations, finance, and strategy, showing how AI lowers barriers to entry, accelerates decision-making, and enables both startups and incumbents to compete more effectively. While AI democratizes powerful tools and boosts productivity, it also raises new risks around bias, concentration, and strategic convergence. To stay ahead, firms must adopt AI thoughtfully, invest cross-functionally, and build the capabilities to scale it responsibly.

title: Multi-Objective Cnn-Lstm for Aircraft Trajectory Prediction with Spatio-Temporal Confidence Areas
affiliations: Université de Toulouse – ONERA, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Zurich University of Applied Sciences

detail.title: Multi-Objective Cnn-Lstm for Aircraft Trajectory Prediction with Spatio-Temporal Confidence Areas
detail.abstract: Accurate and reliable aircraft trajectory prediction is critical for ensuring safety and efficiency in Terminal Manoeuvring Area operations, especially as air traffic volumes continue to rise. However, existing methods often lack confidence metrics, limiting their utility in risk-aware air traffic management. The main contribution of this research is a novel multimodal, joint mean and quantile regression CNN-LSTM model that not only predict aircraft trajectories, but also provides a probabilistic confidence area for the predicted path. By leveraging sequence modelling and uncertainty quantification, the model captures both the trajectory and its associated uncertainty, offering essential information to air traffic controllers about the geographical areas where the aircraft is likely to be in the future. The proposed architecture was evaluated using departure trajectories from Zurich Airport’s Runway 28, incorporating flight data, meteorological conditions, and simulated flight plans. The results demonstrate not only that the predicted trajectory closely matches the ground truth, but also that the predicted confidence intervals align well with empirical observations.

title: Visual Domain Adaptation with Covariance Shift Correction and Feature and Parameter Value Selection Through Pso
affiliations: Indian Institute of Information Technology and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Visual Domain Adaptation with Covariance Shift Correction and Feature and Parameter Value Selection Through Pso
detail.abstract: The main aim of unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) is to minimize the distribution divergence between the labeled source and the unlabeled target domains. While trying to reduce the distribution gap, the other data properties are distorted, reducing the performance of the UDA methods. Thus, we try to apply UDA, keeping the other prominent and relative properties intact, we propose “Visual Domain Adaptation with Covariance Shift Correction and Feature and Parameter Value Selection through PSO” (DACSC), a unified framework of UDA where the most important features are selected using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). Various objectives are used such as maximizing the variance in the target domain, preserving the discriminative information in the source domain using supplied labels, and in the target domain using iteratively optimized pseudo labels, preserving the geometric properties of data in both domains, learning subspace, and between-class and within-class covariance shift correction. The optimal parameters of these ob-jectives are selected using the PSO technique. Applying all the objectives, the proposed method reduces the distribution divergence while keeping the other considerable properties intact. An exhaustive experiment has been performed on diverse benchmark datasets such as PIE-CMU, Office+Caltech (SURF, DeCAF16, and VGG6 features), USPS-MNIST, COIL20, and VLCS datasets to demonstrate the performance of this method and compare with other UDA methods in the visual domain.

title: Need-for-Hedge: How Does Put Warrant Short-Sell Hedging Intensity Affect Equity Lending Market Dynamics?
affiliations: University of New South Wales (UNSW), UNSW Business School and Oregon State University

detail.title: Need-for-Hedge: How Does Put Warrant Short-Sell Hedging Intensity Affect Equity Lending Market Dynamics?
detail.abstract: We utilize a novel data panel of institutional short-sell transactions (with identification flags for hedgers and non-hedgers), equity covered put warrant data, and securities lending data based on the Taiwan market to show that put warrant derivatives hedge re-balancing raises borrowing costs (loan fees). The short-sell hedging demand is inelastic to fees. The positive fee effect with increased hedging becomes significantly strong for expensive-to-borrow stocks that have liquid at-the-the-money warrants. Traders who engage in such hedging have a solid motivation to manage downside risk due to price fluctuations and active hedge re-balancing requirements because of the sensitive delta. This risk management requirement is reflected in fees charged by lenders. Our analysis provides insights into whether regulators and investors should be wary of increased bearish trading strategies in the derivatives market, which could inflate short-selling costs in the lending market. We further find that derivatives hedgers’ demand is sensitive to fees before negative earnings announcements, i.e., hedgers’ short-selling demand declines with higher loan fees. This effect reflects the fact that such hedgers short when they expect higher selling pressure, i.e., they sell low. In contrast, we find that the short-selling demand of traders who are not hedgers is positively associated with costs before the negative earnings information because they feel an urgency to generate profit with overvalued stocks; in other words, they sell high when in receipt of private bad news.

title: (All) Italian Cities’ Size Distribution
affiliations: Sapienza University of Rome

detail.title: (All) Italian Cities’ Size Distribution
detail.abstract: By revisiting well-established empirical regularities, this paper investigates the distributional properties of city size in Italy over the period 2001–2024. Three main findings emerge. First, when considering the entire population of approximately 7,900 municipalities, city sizes are well approximated by a log-normal distribution. Second, in line with Gibrat’s law, city population growth rates appear to be independent of initial city size. Third, the upper tail of the distribution conforms to Zipf’s law, although the results are sensitive to the choice of truncation threshold. The implications of these findings are discussed in relation to urban dynamics and regional inequality.

title: Unsupervised Semantic Segmentation of 3d Point Clouds Based on Enhanced Memory and Feature
affiliations: Wenzhou University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Unsupervised Semantic Segmentation of 3d Point Clouds Based on Enhanced Memory and Feature
detail.abstract: Three-dimensional point cloud semantic segmentation aims to accurately assign semantic labels to individual points. However, this task presents several challenges, including the inherent disorder of point cloud data, the irregularity of geometric structures, and the uneven distribution of point density. In unsupervised 3D point cloud semantic segmentation, performance is hindered by two key obstacles: limitations in the sample distribution of feature learning and insufficient discriminability of feature representations. To address these challenges, we propose a novel framework that integrates a Memory Enhancer and an AttnPnP module. The framework employs cross-batch diverse contrastive learning to mitigate pseudo-label noise and enhance feature discriminability, issues stemming from reliance on single-batch features. Additionally, InfoNCE loss is applied at the superpoint level to reinforce intra-primitive feature compactness and inter-primitive separation. Finally, the AttnPnP module refines feature representations by enforcing local geometric and global semantic constraints.Extensive experiments demonstrate that our framework improves the mean intersection over union from 44.5% to 47.04% on the S3DIS dataset and from 13.1% to 14.79% on the SemanticKITTI dataset, surpassing the baseline performance. The proposed approach significantly enhances feature generalization and semantic clustering precision in unsupervised 3D semantic segmentation, offering an innovative and practical solution for advancing unsupervised 3D scene understanding.

title: Strategic Metal Tellurium Speciation in Skarn-Type Copper Tailings: Redox-Driven Transformations, Environmental Risk, and Secondary Resource Recovery
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Science and Technology of China (USTC) - CAS Key Laboratory of Crust-Mantle Materials and the Environments

detail.title: Strategic Metal Tellurium Speciation in Skarn-Type Copper Tailings: Redox-Driven Transformations, Environmental Risk, and Secondary Resource Recovery
detail.abstract: Skarn-type copper mine tailings can harbor elevated concentrations of critical elements such as tellurium (Te), whose speciation and mobility remain underexplored. We report that Te is moderately enriched (~21 ppm) in the Shuimuchong tailings (Tongling, China) with distinct vertical stratification. Multi-scale analytical techniques (ICP-MS, XRD, TIMA, XPS) reveal trace Te occurring as native Te and telluride minerals (e.g., tetradymite), encapsulated in garnet and pyrite near the surface and present as larger discrete phases at depth. Te concentrations peak at ~26-27 ppm around 10-20 cm depth, coinciding with less-weathered horizons. Redox stratification governs Te speciation: surface oxidation produces soluble Te(IV) oxyanions (tellurite) while deeper anoxic conditions preserve elemental Te(0). Consequently, oxidized Te(IV) in shallow tailings is more mobile and poses greater leaching and ecotoxic risk, whereas reduced Te(0) at depth remains immobile. Our findings underscore occurrence patterns of tellurium, as a strategic mineral in the tailings: the risk of toxic Te release from surface weathering with the secondary-resource potential of Te sequestered in deeper layers.

title: Exclusion and Further Marginalization of Socio-Economically Disadvantaged Young Students: A Qualitative Thematic Analysis in Bangladesh Perspective
affiliations: National University Bangladesh and National University Bangladesh

detail.title: Exclusion and Further Marginalization of Socio-Economically Disadvantaged Young Students: A Qualitative Thematic Analysis in Bangladesh Perspective
detail.abstract: Education for socio-economically disadvantaged students is challenging. These students are always at considerable risk of exclusion and further marginalization in education and societal processes. This study aims to investigate the existing scenario of marginalization and exclusion of young students in Bangladesh and find plausible ways to solve the issue.  This paper is based on a qualitative phenomenological study combining an ethnographic research approach and thematic analysis with empirical data. Primary data were collected through in-depth interviews using a semi-structured questionnaire from teachers, parents of marginalized students, and education officers. After collecting data, they were transcribed into Word files. This study analyzed data using NVivo-15 software and found several themes and sub-themes through coding the interviewees’ descriptions. The study has explored the major causes of marginalization and exclusion, which are parents’ illiteracy and unconsciousness, the impact of family poverty, social environments, and the adverse role of teachers and school authority. Lack of counselling and negative attitudes of teachers and school authorities lead the marginalized students to exclusion. The authors have found several recommendations from respondents to fight against marginalization and exclusion; those are shown in five sub-themes: economic development, social movements, communication and counselling, government and legal actions, and supervision and collaboration. Additionally, this study has revealed the inconsistency between education theory and policy and education practice. The circumstances in which disadvantaged children grow and the interactions they experience at school have a deep impact on their future development because school instigates marginalization, failing to consider individual pupils’ needs.

title: Data Markets as Engines of Long-Run Growth: Insights from the Era of the Digital Economy
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Chinese Academy of Sceinces

detail.title: Data Markets as Engines of Long-Run Growth: Insights from the Era of the Digital Economy
detail.abstract: This paper explores how digital transformation interacts with data markets and their combined impact on long-term economic growth. We develop an endogenous growth model featuring expanding product varieties, in which data is generated as a by-product of consumption and utilized as a nonrival input in production. Firms incur a one-time fixed cost to undergo digital transformation, creating multiple equilibrium possibilities depending on the presence of a data market. Our results demonstrate that digital transformation sustainably enhances economic growth only when supported by an active data market. Although digital transformation initially crowds out market entry, this effect is temporary and does not resolve persistent entry insufficiency caused by monopolistic markups. Extending the analysis to heterogeneous firms, we further reveal that early adopters of digital technologies gain stronger market power, highlighting additional distributional implications of entering the data economy

title: Social and Economic Motivation for Pro-Conservation Agriculture: Evidence from Experimental Simulations
affiliations: University of Vermont, University of Maine, University of Vermont and University of Vermont

detail.title: Social and Economic Motivation for Pro-Conservation Agriculture: Evidence from Experimental Simulations
detail.abstract: We developed a serious agricultural game that tested effects of changing risk on intrinsic motivation to achieve a fictional conservation award: the Ecobadge. In our advanced online experiment, we introduce (1) policy regulation, i.e., fines or incentives; (2) scenarios with high or low risk of penalty fines; and (3) bronze, silver, and gold Ecobadge tiers that could be attained by adopting pro-conservation practices. We recruited 399 participants to make decisions over a cumulative 7,980 simulated years, observing that participants sacrificed a higher USD payout to achieve, most commonly, tier two `silver' Ecobadge (45\% of all decision years). This nonmonetary award system embedded within our simulation based experiment allows us to identify effects of policy and social interaction on farm management decisions. We found that installing a riparian buffer strip significantly increased the odds that participants would apply a higher amount of manure. We also unveil potential ripple effects of policy: combining a fine for excess nutrient runoff with an incentive for no-till management increased the odds participants applied less manure. In our post-experiment survey we asked participants to rate their agricultural knowledge, and then tested their actual knowledge, finding that correct answers were significantly correlated with pro-conservation behavior and vice versa. Interestingly, self-reported agricultural knowledge correlated with anti-conservation farm management when risk of a fine was high. To improve the efficiency of future conservation policies seeking to motivate farmers, here we use serious games to examine the effects of nonmonetary awards and policy interventions.
